dialogues.text: Half your profit. He smiles nervously, thinking Cortes will erupt angrily. Instead Cortes stares at him with an expression close to Then he sticks out his hand. Diero stares at the hand, hesitates (should he ask for mo shakes. The deal is done.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Nothing is that easy.  Meaning: he won't pay. He opens the shutters, stares out at the rain. We study his face. Cheekbones rising, nostrils flaring sl Something is happening to him. Something dramatic. Like a turning into a butterfly...only this is masculine. He crosses the room and pulls a curtain. Revealing: A MAP of "THE KNOWN WORLD." Europe is carefully drawn but dispropor tionately large and central. Africa is sketched huge, vague. South America does not exist at all. Below North America is Cuba, and below Cuba is the Yucata Handwritten on the Yucatan: "Per Cordoba and Grijalva exp Cortes stares at the map and dips his quill into ink. From the Yucatan, he draws an arrow Westward. Deep into what we now know to be Pacific Ocean, his pen s He draws a question mark. Stares at it. Sets down his quill... The fire in his eyes would light a city.

dialogues.text: Men load a ship. Some plain and rough, some gentry; even are tough, self-made men, rather than limp aristocrats. Cortes' banner flies high over a line of recruiting table the dock. We move down the line:

dialogues.text: Which expedition were you on?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND RECRUIT, WITH SCAR, (VILLAFANA)

dialogues.text: .a business venture! If you contribute money, a musket, a horse, then you get extra Shares.

dialogues.text: I wrote to your father, not you! You're too young! He's addressing Gonzalo de SANDOVAL, whose enthusiasm, in slight stammer make him very likeable and somewhat comic.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: I'm t-t-twenty-two!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Exactly. Tend to your pimples.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL

As Sandoval steps aside, the Third Interviewer (JUAN VELA LEON, 27) mutters something to Cortes about the applicant interviewing: PEDRO DE ALVARADO, 34, a golden boy with lo a massive physique, a gold chain, and sublime confidence.

dialogues.text: Isn't trouble what we're looking for? I'm stronger than any man in your army, and happier, I can wiggle my ears, and I can pulla horse down with one hand. Cortes stares at him. But his stare is interrupted by a t squawking from the other end of the dock. Cortes glances turns back to Alvarado:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Step over there. Alvarado saunters to one side as the commotion moves towa CRISTOBAL DE OLID, protesting loudly, is being dragged by Olid is so strong he could toss the others into the drink sense he's actually coming of his own free will.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Senor Cristobal! So nice of you to visit. How are your headaches?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: Try to make me join, I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No, no, you misunderstand. I brought you here for a contest of strength.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: Don't bore me.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: This man claims he can beat you.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Not just you. I can beat anybody.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (motions: see?) | Please. Teach him some humility.

Alvarado grabs the outstretched hand, and they commence. display of raw strength. CORTES' PAGE sprints down the dock and whispers to Cortes Cortes turns to PUERTOCARRERO, a shy, handsome nobleman.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We're sailing. Only way to get satisfaction is to come along. Cristobal glares. Cortes takes him aside, ignoring Diero'

dialogues.text: What is it, my friend?

dialogues.text: Looking back, I have often wondered how many men, in Cortes' place, would even have made it out of port? As the Soldiers move to shackle Cortes, he says loudly:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: But I must caution you. These men already feel loyalty to me. I can't be responsible for what they might do to your town, or your person -

dialogues.speaker: DIERO
dialogues.text: (outraged) You are inciting them to -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (quiet confidence) No. If I incite them, you'll know it. (as Diero hesitates) We sail in ten minutes. (giving him his excuse ) What a pity you didn't get here in time to stop us. Diero nods. He will accept this ploy.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You cowardly sack of slime. (as Diero bridles) Just a figure of speech. (embracing him, whispers: ) Don't forget your 50%!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES

dialogues.text: Men relaxing, enjoying the victory. Cortes sits under a c palms and watches as his Page leads a horse toward him.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This battle gave our Captain his first brilliant idea. A small mare was in heat. Cortes shakes his head, directs his Page to a different s Satisfied, Cortes nods and the mare is tethered. She squa her bottom on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes under the same palm trees; the mare is gone. abbrned chvers have holes in their Lips and-eare-tn which stone disks have been inserted. Cortes leads the Caciques to the spot where the mare was They bow to him; he bows back. No-one to translate. Cortes signals, and his Page leads a STALLION WITH RIDER The horse whinnies loudly, smells the ground, snorts, paw ground... He's staring right at the Indians... The Indians cower. Why is this beast so angry at them? Cortes mimes: he wants food. The Indian Chiefs nod anxiously and back away in fear -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Indian procession. Porters bringing food, followed by BEAUTIFUL NATIVE GIRLS (nine naked to the waist), and las CHIEFS. In the center, supported by several men because h large to walk, is the FAT CACIQUE, their leader.  19.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As Cortes requested, food came... and other gifts. But these Indians were not the ones we'd been fighting. Instead, they came from Cempoala. We were learning that, as in ancient Greece, the land here was divided not into countries, but into city- states. As the half-naked girls approach, the Spaniards - Cristob especially - stare with undisguised lust...

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: I like the one in green. Cristobal sticks out his hand: arm-wrestle?

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, no, you're champion now. You pick first.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: (nods, stares) Actually, I like them all. The Fat Cacique arrives in front of Cortes, dismounts fro with some difficulty, and attempts to bow. Cortes stifles a smile and bows back LATER. Nine Indian Girls are being baptized by Father Olmeda as Captains look on, admiring the girls' breasts...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I trust no man casts a lascivious eye on a religious ceremony...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: The contrary. We are filled with awe at what the Lord has created. Velasquez De Leon approaches, preceded by the tallest and beautiful of the Native Girls, MARINA, still fully clothe

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Captain, this one speaks Spanish. as Cortes looks her over) She claims to have been a princess.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Malinali Tenepal. You will call me Marina.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I will, eh? How did you learn Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: When my father died, my mother the Queen sold me as a Slave to favor the children of her second husband. Another slave, with me, was a Spaniard.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: From which expedition? She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is this Spaniard now?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Gone. (i.e., dead)

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: He was your lover, then?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (flat) No. Cortes stares at her. She stares back. A pride both admir infuriating...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: So...your own family, your own mother, betrayed you.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: She betrayed herself. He stifles a smile of appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Since you are a princess and deserve the best, I give you... (looks over his men, seems to focus on Alvarado) to my good friend...Puertocarrero. Puertocarrero steps forward, blinking, shy but quite plea shoots him the briefest glance.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, you will be on call day and night as my translator. Conch shell trumpets sound.  21. A cortege of ornately dressed INDIANS approaches. Their c hairstyle, and manner all set them apart from the Cempoal In fact, the Fat Cacique is being carried toward a dense Mangrove trees. He's gesturing frantically: hurry, hurry! The rest of his tribe precedes him. In seconds, they are glances at Marina, then at the approaching Indians -

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Aztecs. They have conquered most of these towns from a city, Mexico, high in the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Mexico? Where the gold is?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They call it "excrement of the Gods."

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then you - you're not an Aztec?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Never. The Mexicans conquered m city, They rule harshly, throug ear. Her eyes dart toward the woods where the Cempoalans are h Cortes follows her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Good. She shoots him a glance. Why "good?" The AZTECS arrive. Their simple cloaks and sandals evoke the Ancient Greeks. On the other hand, their ears, lips, and noses are garnis pendants formed of precious stones. SERVANTS cloud the air with copal incense, others display THREE PRINCES touch the ground, then their heads, in gree speak alternately, diffusing their identity.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They come from the great Lord Moctezuma who sends these gifts as a token of friendship. They say his capital is too far to travel to, and the road beset with too many enemies...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Good God.  22. The Servants have set out two magnificent circular plates silver, the other gold, both as large as carriage wheels. plate represents the moon, the gold one the sun. Both are wrought with calendar signs and images of Gods. Cortes' young PAGE (who, through dress and manner, sugges coming of the modern mercantile age) steps forward to rec

dialogues.speaker: PAGE
dialogues.text: The gold plate alone is worth 20,000 pesos and the workmanship surpasses anything in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: These bribes whet my appetite.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: We Indians say: the greater the gift, the greater the King.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Tell them I too come from a powerful King who orders me to pay personal respects to Lord Moctezuma, of whose greatness he has long heard tell. As I have had a difficult journey over the sea, I dare not return home without seeing Moctezuma face to face.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: King Carlos doesn't know - Cortes silences him with a look - One of the Aztec Princes replies testily:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: "You hardly arrive and you insist on seeing on our Emperor's face?" One Prince points at something, and the others jabber exc Cortes watches this, then glances inquiringly at Marina.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They call you "Teules." Gods. Or perhaps those sent by the Gods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes nods thoughtfully...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing) That soldier's helmet reminds them of the War God Huitzilopochtli. Cortes whispers to his Page, who runs to fetch the gilt h  23.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: They may take this helmet to show the great Moctezuma. В«providing they return it filled with gold. we Spanish suffer a disease of the heart which can only be cured by gold. He gestures, and four horses approach, their bells jingli The Aztecs stand, mouths agape, watching the horses. An Aztec scribe quickly paints the horses onto bark paper already sketched Cortes, Marina, and the Spanish ships.

dialogues.speaker: ON CORTES AND MARINA
dialogues.text: Walking together.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The helmet, horses. Is that why they call us Gods?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Your looks, ships, clothing - it's all strange to them. You are not like men. So what are you?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (nods, answers: ) Gods. Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They mentioned the great Teule Quetzalcoatl. 500 years ago he sailed to the East, promising to return. He had light hair, like some of your men. Perhaps you are him. Perhaps King Carlos is. Perhaps this, your coming, fulfills an ancient prophecy. (as Cortes thinks) You must know: to the Aztec, prophecy is law. It is even the same word. We see a thousand calculations race through Cortes' mind.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You say the Aztecs rule, but the other cities hate and fear them?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then we can win.  24. They've reached the woods where the Fat Cacique and the o Cempoalans are hiding.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ask him if he is a vassal of the great Moctezuma? She speaks; the Fat Cacique quickly replies:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: "who is not?" Tell him we will protect him. we are Gods, and our will is indomitable. He watches the Indian Chief's face as Marina translates. Then his eyes turn to her: Clearly he finds her impressiv He looks back at the Fat Cacique:

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Cortes' words had the desired effect, but he was soon to learn...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SPANISH CAMP. HOURS LATER.
dialogues.text: As Spanish troops admire Moctezuma's gifts, Velasquez De Cristobal approach Cortes' tent. He sits outside polishin

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...that our will, of which he spoke with such pride, was already weakening.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: It is time to return to Cuba. Cortes stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: We speak for many of the men.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Is something wrong with the girl I gave you?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: No, she's very...primitive... (smile, then frown) but so are the mosquitos here they've activated my skin rashes -  25.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: And considering the gifts Moctezuma has already given us -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Do you leave the table if the appetizer is savory?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: We were sent here to make contact To_ trade! We have done so. We have gold beyond our expectations -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Whose expectations?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: And - most important - we have done our duty and completed our mission. Anything more would be mutiny. Cortes stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You're right. Of course. We sail in the morning. Cristobal grins, de Leon is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please spread word among the men.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER.
dialogues.text: From a distance we see the news disseminating and the exp incredulity and outrage it evokes. An angry crowd is descending on Cortes' tent. Cortes continues to polish his boots, seemingly oblivious uproar. But his attention is focused on: Outside a nearby tent, Puertocarrero and Marina sit on th

dialogues.speaker: AN HOUR LATER.
dialogues.text: The whole Spanish company assembled in front of Cortes' t Captain is arguing with Alvarado, Puertocarrero, others:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: But I cannot exceed my authority!

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Hang your authority! What about your duty to us? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promsВҐBaRQQ0вЂ™GeNdsDand glory! Are we to return home like gypsies with a few trinkets? Cortes stares at him, at the others. He jumps up on a makeshift table, and the men quiet.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The decision I made earlier has caused great dissention. Cheers and angry shouts from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I realize now I cannot fulfill my moral obligation to you and also to the esteemed Governor of Cuba. Honor therefore requires that I resign my post. He jumps down from the table. Stunned silence. Murmurs in the crowd. What does this mean? What happens n choose a new leader? Sandoval glances quickly at Cortes, as if for a sign. Cortes gives none. Velasquez de Leon watches as: Sandoval waits... Looks around... Bites his lip and gives another glance - Very subtly: Cortes nods - Sandoval jumps on the table. Speaking publicly, his stutt

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: If Cortes is loyal to us, are we loyal to him!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Do we want a new leader?

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Then who must we serve, the Governor of Cuba, or the King of Spain?!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: The King of Spain!  27.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: (wry, to Cortes) This is very well done.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Then let us found a new city, in the name of the King: As the Crowd cheers, Velasquez de Leon mutters sarcastica

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: "And there is only one man..."

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: And there is only one man to be mayor of our city... As the Crowd drowns him out -

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORTES' TENT. LATER.
dialogues.text: Cortes and Father Olmeda with the major Hidalgos.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We are now outlaws. If we fail to conquer, if we cannot seize riches which will blind the King, then we'll all hang for treason. We will therefore approach King Carlos directly, give him the treasures Moctezuma has sent, and beg him to grant us supremacy. (turns to Puertocarrero an another Hidalgo) Since you have relatives in court, you two can best plead our cause.

dialogues.speaker: PUERTOCARRERO
dialogues.text: And my Indian concubines?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Show one as a curiosity to the King. Marina, of course, must stay here, to translate.

dialogues.speaker: PUERTOCARRERO
dialogues.text: Of course. He smiles, realizing he has been chosen because Cortes de Marina. He and the other Hidalgo kneel in front of Father makes the sign of the cross over them. They kiss his hand  28. EXT. TENT. DAY. Cortes and Father Olmeda watch the two emissaries walk do the shore and the ships.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Puertocarrero's ship was the last of our fleet ever to leave port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spanish army building a stone fort. Cortes deposits a boulder next to a "mason" and heads off for another stone He passes Martin Lopez adding "Villa Rica de Vera Cruz" t

dialogues.speaker: MAP
dialogues.text: (See Next Page) OPEN FIELD. Under _a tree where several men are being kept prisoner, himself down beside the shackled Velasquez de Leon:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Velasquez knew we would betray him. He himself forced our hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Velasquez De Leon says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By withholding funds, he made us spend our own fortunes, which we did, mortgage our homes, which we did. He cannot then expect us to return home and suffer bankruptcy!

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Nevertheless: Velasquez is my relative, and I remain loyal.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I admire that. I will release you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: (surprised, but:) Why not today? Now?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You need time to think

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: About what?  29.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The purpose for which you are born.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Oh please.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Do you really want to return to Cuba and live the life of a nobleman, feasting off the labor of others and seducing your neighbor's wives?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Sounds pleasurable.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: It is pleasurable. And common. Any Frenchman can do it. But here... If we have courage, intelligence, spirit, we can achieve something remarkable. And the most remarkable part is: We don't know what we're about to do! We only know that if we succeed, we will have been truly alive. And years from now, centuries, others will look back and say, "Cortes was aman. Velasquez De Leon?. A man." Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers De Leon some water. The other man hesitates, th

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Thank you. He drinks. Cortes takes the bottle back, returns to work. Velasquez De Leon stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Olmeda looks on as Alvarado pounds into the ground smaller crucifixes they brought on the boat. Behind them: The Spanish Army is marching through countryside of unspe lushness and beauty. Tropical birds singing. Orchids bloo wild. The Mastiff chasing plentiful game. The army is - f moment - optimistic, united in its purpose, and enthralle natural beauty of the scenery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We built a fort at our new city of Vera Cruz and marched toward Cempoala. They approach a small town.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was on our way to the home of the Fat Cacique that we first saw evidence of the religious practice 30. which engendered fear in our hearts and outrage in our Christian souls for as long as we were in New Spain. The town seems deserted. The Soldiers move through it, but some instinct quiets th They approach prominent buildings and glance inside. Sandoval stands motionless in the entrance to the largest church or cue). Is he frozen? Then he turns toward the ot Blanches. Starts to stutter uncontrollably... Cortes moves to his side, looks in: INT. CUE. DAY. No windows. Dark, lit by a few torches. Primitive statues of heathen gods. Bodies. Human bodies, carved up. Some impaled on the walls. Stacks of skulls along another wall. Human organs burning over a fire. Cortes turns away, toward Father Olmeda.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Father, give me strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rinky-dink parade. Girls throwing flowers, putting wreath Spaniards' necks. Hail the conquering heroes. Everyone st waving at the Teules. Lush vegetation makes this modest town feels like a garde The procession ends at the lavish home of the Fat Cacique greet the Spanish Captains and lead them into: EXT. FAT CACIQUE'S PATIO. DAY. Cortes, Marina, and the other Hidalgos at a huge feast. T Cacique is stuffing himself, jabbering happily:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He regrets that only nine of his wives can be here to serve us.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: How many wives does he have? As Marina translates, the others eat with evident relish.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He's lost count. The more you have, the more alliances you make. Also the more children, which allows you to make even more alliances when they grow up. (hesitates, then translates: ) He says it's his duty as a chief to spend most of his time in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs...then they notice: something odd in the Cacique 's expression. He is no longer laughing. He is st dread out at the street where: FIVE MEN with dark glossy hair tied in a bun, wearing ric embroidered cloaks, stroll with cocksure pride through th They sniff bouquets of flowers while SERVANTS whisk away stiff walk, their arrogance, tells us: these men are kill At the sight of them, the Fat Cacique turns pale, starts

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Moctezuma's tax-collectors. They rape the pretty women and sacrifice the men."

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (blithe instinct) Arrest them. Marina hesitates to translate this. Cortes nods: translate.  32. She does. The Fat Cacique falls to the ground and begs for Cortes'

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell him he has nothing to fear As Marina translates, the Fat Cacique continues to babble infant and roll on the ground. Cortes crouches over the man. Staring. Their eyes lock. No contest. The Fat Cacique whispers an order, and his SOLDIERS rush They begin to arrest the astonished Tax Collectors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes lies on his bedroll; Marina stands nearby. A knock, and Sandoval enters.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: The locals saw n-n-nothing. Cortes nods - go ahead with the plan. Sandoval waves his arm, and FOUR SOLDIERS carry in two of Tax Collectors, tied to long poles.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: to Marina) Ask them who they are and where they're from. (to Soldiers) Untie them. (to Sandoval) Have food brought to the next tent.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Can I w-watch what you do? Cortes nods slightly as -

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They say you know who they are, since you are responsible for their capture. The Cempoalans wouldn't dare arrest them on their own.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If this were true, would I now release them, and feed them, and treat them as Kings? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sak@WVEB( CON MAD: na translates) Convincing?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They think it's a trick. "If they are released here, the Cempoalans will recapture and kill them."

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Our boats will take them South to safer waters. (watches Marina translate, then says to her: I am impressed you betray nothing in your expression.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: What is to betray? Meaning: I_am_on your side, I have no other loyalties. He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Now I must ask them to go next door and eat. I have private business. (as Marina starts to leave) With you.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: What do you want? Sandoval hurries the Tax-Collectors out -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: A kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Only one?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I ask for one. Anything more is a gift.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: If I refuse? Hard to tell if she wants to refuse or is being coy.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If your refusal is genuine, I will respect it. If it is a game, I will not. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I will kiss you twice...but only if you order it.  34. She speaks with intensity. We can't tell if she is being provocative. He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Take off your clothes. She starts to disrobe. On her lips, the faintest hint of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes sits in front of the Fat Cacique's house, the Chie side, Marina behind him. The Captain seems distant, keenl as though listening to music no one else can hear. The Three additional Tax Collectors are brought before th Cortes, feigning anger, gestures toward the Fat Cacique.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm outraged by the escape of the two prisoners. We will have to guard the ones who remain. (as Marina translates, to de Leon) Same as the others. Sail them South and release them. (to Sandoval) Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: The C-Cempoalans are Forced to be our ally. But Moctezuma.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Are we Gods or men, friend or foe? He will have to see us for himself. (sudden shift) What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: How do you m-mean?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Over there. He indicates TWO SOLDIERS whispering back and forth. Sandoval shrugs: so? Cortes catches the eye of one Soldier who glances furtive

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Search the camp.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: For what?  35.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Whatever you find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes, Sandoval, Marina, and Velasquez de Leon stare at: Food, barrels of water, maps, etc. Provisions. Cortes is clearly: enraged...

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORTES' TENT. SUNSET.
dialogues.text: The best men congregated. An uncomfortable silence...

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Some of you know what happened. Some do not.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: M-m-mutiny.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: No! For what cause?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Men were stashing provisions to return to Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: A worthy cause, but treacherous means! Let me kill the vermin - Velasquez De Leon raises the flap in the tent, making vis The body of a GAUNT SOLDIER hanging from a tree. Cristobal nods with satisfaction -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (softly) We must act. Silence. They wait.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If a wild beast has no escape, it fights with twice the ferocity. We must do that to ourselves.  36. Silence as they try to figure out what this means...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers stand by their tents, peering at the distant where the ships rise and fall with the swell of the ocean No one moves. Everyone waits. For what? An order? Then we see: flames licking at the bow of one of the ship The men tense, but say nothing. The fire rises higher, up the mast. Another ship explodes into flame. EXT. SHIPS. NIGHT. Cortes himself with a torch setting a ship aflame. His ey crazed, as if possessed by some demon. Pyromania. When th well lit, he dodges through the flames, climbs over the s lifeboat, and heads for the next vessel. His torch held h air... EXT. CAMP. NIGHT. Soldiers still watching. Ten ships now burning. Cervantes bearded buffoon we met earlier) is putting on a song/danc common soldier, VILLAFANA.

dialogues.speaker: CERVANTES
dialogues.text: They say the hulls were rotten! They say we could not sail! They think our brains are cotton! Or hidden up our tail!

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CERVANTES
dialogues.text: (facetious) But don't you understand? This way we salvage the sails and the provisions -

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: (ominous ) I understand perfectly. Velasquez De Leon has happened by, overheard:

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Like it or not, we have to fight our way out of here.  37. Nearby, we see Cortes on his way back from the shore. His blackened, but his spirit is ectatic. Cristobal intercept

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: I hate you for this.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Never. Cortes gives him a long look...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then you may leave. One vessel is still seaworthy. Those who desire to go may sail to Cuba. You organize the sailing. Cristobal is astonished. He bows acceptance, and leaves. Cortes watches as Cristobal starts conferring with other

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMP. TWO DAYS LATER.
dialogues.text: Men breaking break camp (folding tents, loading horses). approaches Cortes and hands him a list Cortes examines the list...and sadly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, you're my best soldier. (off Cristobal's blink) I can't let you go.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: That's not fair when others are -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I'm not letting the others either I just wanted this list.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: But...but you said -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I lied. The last ship was sunk this morning. Cortes points: Cristobal looks toward the bay: it's empty. No ships rema turns, outraged and astonished, back toward:  38.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: waving list) I have to know who has doubts, but we'll need every single man, even the doubters, if we are to succeed. Cristobal blinks in disbelief - Cortes slaps him good-naturedly on the back

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cloud of pink butterflies. The Spanish Army marches thr followed by a small group of Indian warriors and PORTERS. Three of the Porters are burdened with heavy piles of cru crosses the Spaniards brought with them on their ships. T these innocent natives bearin symbols of human guilt is d ironic because of the magic of these surroundings: woods waterfalls meadows sky mountains rising and falling... fields of flowers of raucous color... It all strikes some atavistic memory: Long ago, before "c man wrecked his havoc, this is how the world used to be.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We saw no bird, no flower, no tree or animal we had ever seen in Spain. It truly was a New World. Cortes pauses to survey his surroundings. Snowy peak on t a strange bleak mountain, topped with a black coffin-shap the right. In the distance, two volcanos spew ash. Martin Lopez is adding these features to his map.

dialogues.speaker: MAP
dialogues.text: (See Next Page)  39. EXT. MOUNTAIN PINE FORESTS. DAY. Thick woods. Cortes listens as an Indian guide points upw

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We were marching to a city-state called Tlascala. Cortes resumes the march. Behind him, other Spaniards pic along the trail...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: By their courage, and their location high in these mountains the Tlascalans have kept their independence from the Aztecs. Cortes suddenly stops, yanks something from his collar, a to the ground. A piece of colored paper. We notice: A series of threads hang across the trail. Dangling from bits of paper in odd shapes and bright colors.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charms. To keep us out. From a distance we see Cortes slice the threads with his Pov tells us: he's being watched.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Send our message again: "If blood is spilled, it is on their heads. We come in peace, seeking allies." A distinctively dressed MESSENGER sprints away - Suddenly, by a camera trick, we see INDIANS in the forest them. Staring, motionless. They seem to be of the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. Two tiny native dogs sniff the huge Spanish Mas of the square: lattice-work cages containing captives...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Men to be sacrificed. Cortes cuts the leather lock and throws open the cage. Some captives run. Those who seem stronger and braver do tries to chase them away, shouting and waving his sword.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Go! Run! Flee, you morons! (lunging with his sword) What, you want to die?  40.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Aztecs.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Are Aztecs so stupid?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They learn from birth: the greatest honor is to die in battle or be sacrificed as a prisoner of war Cortes stares at them, the foe he will soon face: FIVE ME him blankly: without fear, without pride, without affect.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Make them kneel. | as his men hesitate) Make them kneel if you have to cut off their feet! Spaniards force the prisoners to their knees. Cortes removes the cross from his neck and holds it over

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Father, say a mass for the souls of these poor devils. Olmeda begins. The Spaniards fall to their knees. All of them. The movem down the hill until even those who cannot see, let alone joined the prayer. After a slight hesitation, Marina also kneels. For a moment, we are witnessing a religious ceremony... Then, spectators: EIGHT PAPAS proceed slowly, one by one, out of a nearby c dressed in dark green hooded cloaks decorated with images and Gods. Their thick hair hangs to their feet and is mat blood. Evil magicians out of Dr. Seuss. Their fingernails long, and they click them as they walk. Olmeda ignores them. The other Spaniards want to rise, bu so without being disrespectful to their God. The Papas march round the cage, uttering incantations. Cortes shoots Marina an enquiring look -

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Priests. They're called Papas -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: They stink.  41.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Blood. From sacrifices, and from stabbing themselves with thorns. They are the sons of Chiefs, have no wives, and they indulge in sodomy. Cortes stares at the Papas in astonishment and disgust. The Mastiff barks furiously at the Papas and strains at i One Papa brings something from under his robe: A human heart dripping blood. He holds it under Cortes' nose.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's trying to see if you're a God. (off Cortes' look) A God would eat it. The heart, inches from Cortes' mouth. His nostrils flare. Hard to stifle the homicidal impulse. in the midst of a Latin phrase:

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: To arms. It takes a second for this to register. The Papas scurry away - The barking Mastiff falls dead, arrow in its chest -

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To arms, men! To battle! The Spaniards look up: INDIANS descending - The sky darkens with stones and arrows - The Spaniards rise, fumble for weapons. Several men are h arrows - Indians rush forward. Startling attire: great feather cre and faces gaudily painted; Caciques adorned with spectacu headdresses. Cacophony: they bang drums, whistle, blow tr The Spaniards, surprised and overwhelmed, hastily retreat neighboring houses... They load muskets and crossbows. Unsheathe swords. Ready ances... At a signal from Cortes, they move out into the open agai  42. The town is deserted. The Indian army has vanished. The S move forward warily, fearful of another attack... But there is nothing to fear. Nothing to see... Except: a cooking pot lying in the center of the square. In the pot is an Indian tunic...a distinctive one... Some it, examines it...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Your messenger. They killed him ...and ate him...and intend to do the same to you. A wave of horror and disgust passes through the Spaniards counter any fear in his men, Cortes is quite matter-of-fa

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Why don't they believe we seek allies? Marina looks into the pot, takes out a drawing: of a bird

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They think it's a trick and you're secretly in league with the Aztecs. Cortes nods, peers out at the haunting landscape...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: So. It begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide field. Indians marching toward the waiting Spaniards. Tlascalans insults, whipping themselves up into a frenzy. Cortes is in the rear, Sandoval at his side. Sandoval poi front of the Tlascalan ranks.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: We are told their General is Xicotencatl The Younger. XICOTENCATL THE YOUNGER, 65, wears a headdress capped wit of a heron.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The "Younger?" Sandoval points up to a bluff overlooking the battle. XIC ELDER is blind. Two Servants describe the battle to him.  43.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Xicotencatl The Elder is 140 years old and still the greatest Tlascalan chief. A HUGE COMMOTION as the battle is joined. Alvarado scream the Spaniards, cutting a swath through the Indian ranks. The CAMERA PANS over the battlefield until we come to ano on which stand 3 AZTEC SCOUTS:

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Aztecs watched in fear. For centuries they had tried to conquer Tlascala. And failed. There we were, only a few hundred men fighting battle after battle, day after day... Return to the battle. Velasquez de Leon's horse has been He's trying valiantly to protect it, but there are too ma around, and he is finally driven back. The Indians begin, quite crudely, to sever the horse's he

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The head of this horse was borne that night to every city in Tlascala, so the people could see it was not a supernatural creature. The battle rages through A SERIES OF DISSOLVES, as the li

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We fought all day. We fought until we could no longer lift our arms and by some miracle, they retreated... The Indians blow their conch shells, pound their drums, a "Alala! Alala!" They throw straw and dirt into the air to their retreat. Soon a brown cloud hovers over the field.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We hoped our victory might weaken their resolve. As the dirt falls and the air clears, the battlefield is No warriors. No Indian corpses. Where have they gone? Eerie. As if it had all been a mirage...except that a sco Spaniards lie dead in the dirt. Cortes looks at Sandoval, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Won't even let us see their dead.  44. Slowly, cautiously, the Spaniards tend to their fallen co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes (the ever-watchful father), Marina, and Sandoval w camp. They pass men repairing crossbows...making arrows.. Small carcasses being roasted on a spit...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For the third straight night, we had nothing to eat except a few small dogs, and a handful of native igs. Nearby, a small pot boils. Men dip rags into it and apply their wounds.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Every one of was injured. To cauterize our wounds we had to use fat cut from one of the few Indians carcasses we were able to retrieve. A few Soldiers seem disgusted by the human fat in the pot Suddenly A SENTRY calls in the distance. The men rush to their weapons -

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Indians do not attack at night. CORTES ; They only have to do it once. The Men relax as they see: A LONE INDIAN walking toward them waving a flag. Cortes and Marina step forward to meet him. The messenger

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: "Xicotencatl The Younger says: 'If you are tired of fighting, you may come to Tlascala in peace ...and your flesh will be hacked from your bodies and spiced with chilies and eaten with pleasure.'"

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Tell Xicotencatl: a scared man speaks. A brave man acts. I will meet him tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The messenger leaves, and Cortes moves on, passing:  45. Men in bedrolls, wearing their armor, sleeping fitfully o rigid with their eyes open. Farther on is a tent where Father Olmeda is taking confes

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Despite the bravado of our captain there was hardly one of us who did not take confession that night. Inside the tent, a very young SOLDIER is weeping.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We feared death, for we were men. Even Olmeda's voice is quaking slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance we see a lethal confrontation which has c going on for hours. We move:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indians coming like a tidal wave, one leaping over an numerous to fight, too numerous even to discern. The Span are in chaos.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At noon the following day I knew for the first time, knew it in my bones, that I would die in New Spain. The Spaniards look like they've gone down twice and are s for a last breath: Frantic, overwhelmed, unable to proces assaulting them. It seems that soon the wave will rise ag the Spaniards away and only Indians will fill the plain.. But Cortes is fighting cool and strong amid the panic. He a circle, ever in a circle, looking for something we cann Suddenly he stops. Stares in one direction: A FLAG rising above the Indians. Cortes plunges sword first toward it:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Here! Follow me! Here is our mark! He heads toward a CACIQUE with a spectacular head-dress, servants hold the flag. We feel Cortes' will dominating t him. Sandoval and other Hidalgos follow him... The Indians are too ti htly packed to effectively fight b near the Cacique seem bewildered by Cortes' assault.  46. DIAZ (V.O. Among so many Miners, why did Cortes attack this one? Cortes kills the Chief's servants; Sandoval stabs the Chi DIAZ (V.O. Li (CONT'D) We later learned this Cacique was not supposed to fight, not supposed to be attacked. Their Gods had said he would lead them to victory. The Indians around them stand back in horror and watch as Page lifts the Indian banner...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Their prophecy was invalidated. The true fate of this battle was revealed. Cortes pushes onward, and the Tlascalans retreat, wailing sending panic throughout their ranks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men in armor lie in bed moaning, shivering uncontrollably DIAZ (V.O. Though we won the battle, our spirits were defeated. We had lost 50 men on the campaign, others were dying, others had wounds where their arms once were. Wounded sentries keep their hollow-eyed watch...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next morning, the disease within our midst flared again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and Marina emerge to find a delegation headed by:

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: The men we are fighting are our intended allies, far weaker than the Aztecs, and they are defeating us! The idea of reaching Mexico is a joke. I say it; you know it: we cannot survive another battle!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (softly) Where will we find fewer enemies?  47. A strange and almost lyrical query, which silences Cristo looks out at the surrounding countryside:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here in this exotic land, if we retreat or show weakness, the very stones themselves will rise against us. If the natives believe we are Gods, so must we be.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: You be a God. I'm going home. A sound. Cristobal blinks. They all peer down the road: A delegation of unarmed Indians bearing food, wearing whi

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Peace. They're sending food. And porters to prepare it.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: All right. First we eat, then we go home.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LATER.
dialogues.text: Spaniards wolfing down the food. Tlascalans serving it. Friendly, obsequious, observant. Cortes eats with Marina. Something on his mind...

dialogues.speaker: , CORTES
dialogues.text: Didn't you say... Don't Indians sometimes send food to the enemy, so that the battle will be a fair one? Marina nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So if they truly want peace, why didn't Xicotencatl come? Marina shrugs -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ask if they are sent by Xicotencatl the father or the son? As she does this, Cortes observes one of the Tlascalans p a tent. Another has persuaded a Spaniard to show him his  48.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He says the father has ordered eace, and the son has sent them ere. Cortes ponders this...stares at the man being questioned.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Interesting distinction. Ask if he's a spy. Cortes watches as she translates, and the Man shakes his

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut off their hands. Velasquez de Leon and Marina look at him with alarm - He grabs the docile Tlascalan who's serving them. The man sweet, bewildered by this action.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: What if they're not spies?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then I'm wrong. He is holding the man by the wrists, staring at a nearby Soldier hesitantly unsheathes his sword. Cortes nods, and the Soldier brings down his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Cortes stand both Xicotencatls. They bow, touch th with their hands, and kiss their hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: You were right about the spies. Cortes nods, and the Chiefs rise. Xico The Younger speaks

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "I cannot defeat a man who reads my mind." Xicotencatl The Elder moves slowly, arms outstretched, to Reluctantly Cortes allows him to touch his face... finger patting the features; he's muttering...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "The face of a Teule..." On the old man's face: religious ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small ceremony: beautiful VIRGINS being presented to the Marina translating, something about the Indians Joining t families with the Gods. We move away from this spectacle The same Young Soldier we once saw eating an orange now s building. He takes sprouted orange seeds from a wet handk plants them six inches apart and two inches deep, and gen them with soil. This is YOUNG BERNAL DIAZ. Several Tlasca are watching him. As always his voice is old, gravelly:

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There were so many heroes in our campaign it is hard for me to confess that I was only a young boy. Much that I tell I saw with my own eyes, much was told me by others, some was common conjecture. I may not report everything, and some things I have forgotten because I am old, some I never knew, but as a Christian, I swear: I tell nothing I know to be false. Coming up the road is a DELEGATION OF AZTECS. The presentation of the Virgins ends; they go off with pr hidalgos, who by now have several women apiece. Cortes steps forward to meet the Aztecs, who bow, wave th incense, and begin the ritual presentation of gifts.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: "The great Moctezuma salutes your victory." The Aztecs spread out jewelry and cloth embroidered with and return the gilt helmet, now filled with grains of gol Cortes' Page steps forward to give an accounting:

dialogues.speaker: PAGE
dialogues.text: The jewelry is worth 1000 pesos, the helmet with gold 3000. The cloth is beatiful but worthless.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (nods) Bring a pen and scroll. I will write Moctezuma a letter

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: In S-Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: He will see it has meaning and know our writing is more advanced. The Page returns with the materials and prepares to write  50.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Moctezuma: I will not rest until your power is my power, your gold is my gold, your kingdom is mine to hold in my and. I will see that all the souls in this land have given up their devilish idols and sworn devotion to the one True God. (very intense) Some way, some how, at whatever cost, I will achieve these things. Silence. Other Spaniards stunned by the frankness of this The Aztecs watch curiously, wondering what just happened. Cortes smiles broadly, bows, and the Aztecs relax.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Marina) Translate it. "I have the greatest respect for Moctezuma, and so forth..." As Marina begins to "translate," the Aztecs smile and ges kind of invitation.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Aztecs were scared. They knew it was time to confront us, and they did it in the Styest, most sinister way imaginable: they invited us ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An army of Spaniards and indians ready to march. Cortes i a warning/blessing from Xicotencatl the Elder.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: "Now that I know you, I know you eat food, as men do, love women, as men do, and in battle you weary, just as men do. If you go on 100,000 men will fight you. When these are vanquished, that many again will come, and again and again until, though you be invincible, you will grow weary and die. But if you are determined to go, I will send these warriors, and also my three youngest sons, to die by your side." The THREE YOUNGEST SONS look eager and innocent. Xicotenc Younger - not among the three - watches from nearby.  51. Xicotencatl The Elder fervently clutches Cortes' hand...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Tell him to care for his health, so I can see him again when we return. As Marina translates, Cortes jumps on his horse, starts a The procession begins. A magnificent spectacle. Marina walks at Cortes' side:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I was mistaken. The Aztecs are leading us not to Mexico, but to their sister city, Cholula. They say we will be well taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a corner, Martin Lopez adds Cholula to his map. INSERT - MAP. (See Next Page) LARGE HALL. Spaniards being served an enormous feast by beautiful, fl native GIRLS. The clown Cervantes peers skeptically at a sure it does not contain human flesh.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In the religious capital of the Aztec Federation, we were honored by a silly and affectionate people who showered us with flowers and kisses, and cooked the most exquisite delicacies. We were in heaven. We were in hell. Cortes stands by the window, sometimes looking out, somet watching his men. A CHOLULAN GIRL approaches with a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: You don't want to eat? Cortes looks through her, not hearing the question.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: They're whores.  52.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The girls tending us: they're not daughters of noblemen...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Oh relax, will you? These people are harmless fools. Again Cortes doesn't hear. He stares out the window: At either end of the block, pedestrians seem to be avoidi center of the street...

dialogues.speaker: , CORTES
dialogues.text: Marina: go down and see what you see. Cristobal watches her as she leaves:

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Are you certain of her?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: More than of you.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Think with your head, not your groin. She already betrayed her own people. Why not us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide clean streets, pedestrians dressed in long cloaks em Marina walks happily but keeps a keen eye. At the end of the block she notices the peculiar walking which Cortes observed from above. Moving closer, she sees Cloth has been spread on the ground, and dirt thrown over She approaches the cloth. Cholulans watch her silently. Lifting the cloth, she sees a hole in the ground. Spears upward inside the hole. She calls to a nearby PEDESTRIAN. He minces over to her w exaggerated manners of a flamboyant homosexual. She point spears and asks a question. Their conversation is subtitl  53.

dialogues.speaker: PEDESTRIAN
dialogues.text: This is a silly thing we put here to protect Cortes from evil spirits.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: It would do more damage to horses than to spirits. Why are so few women and children in the street? We hadn't noticed this until she said it...

dialogues.speaker: PEDESTRIAN
dialogues.text: They are off to the mountains for vacation.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) For their health? She stands. As she strolls back toward the Spanish quarte glances idly into the sky: a hawk or other large bird cir azily... Her gaze skyward is interrupted by a HANDSOME WOMAN of 45 furtive air who grasps Marina's arm:

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME WOMAN
dialogues.text: You must not return to the white men. (long beat) My son saw you. He does not want you to die.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Why would I die?

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mexico has sent an army. The white men will never leave our city alive. Marina kisses the woman's hand and stares gratefully into

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Wait here. I will fetch my jewels. Marina walks slowly toward the building where the Spanish can't tell what she's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marina staring at Cortes... We assume this is the moment deciding whether to tell him.  54. She starts to speak. Before she can, Cortes turns to her indicates TWO NEARBY PAPAS:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We leave for Mexico in the morning. Ask them to provide us with orters, and to have the city's eaders in the square so we may bid them a proper farewell. Cortes leaves the room, going into: AN ADJOINING ROOM. When he closes the door, we see: the Handsome Woman bound Two Soldiers guard her.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I told you before. Kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and Marina.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Why did you tell me? off her silence) This was a chance to be a hero to your own people.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I have no people.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Even so - She puts her fingers to his lips, silencing him.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Tell yourself this: Once I was a princess. Now, at your side, I ama queen. Malinche. They even call yu by my name. What more could I ask? He nods his understanding. But her expression betrays mor the truth is, she does everything because of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes sits on his horse. Marina and Father Olmeda stand They are surrounded by the Spanish Army. 3000 Cholulans pack the square, including Papas, Caciques Cortes gestures to his Page, who bangs a large atabel.  55. Silence. His words fill it. Marina simultaneously transla

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Dear friends. We are grateful for the extraordinary hospitality you have extended in so short a time. Spaniards put a screen across one entrance to the square.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have fed us, pampered us, and freely given us...your whores. A second screen closes a second entrance. Horsemen with s their places in front of the screen. CORTES (CONT' Dy We know that you are allies of Moctezuma, that you must take orders from him, and that sometimes those orders run contrary to your wishes and your own sweet nature. The third screen is put up. Horsemen take their places.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For example, we know he has sent an army, now on the outskirts of your city, which plans to attack us with your help. The Cholulans look around in confusion and alarm. Why is this? How does he know it? Why is his tone so mild? The screen for the fourth and last entrance to the square TwO SOLDIERS try vainly to put it into place as:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And we know you have given help. You have put stakes in the street, stacked rocks on the roofs of your houses, evacuated women and children, and you intended to slaughter us, even though we are your guests. Cortes looks at the last entrance: still open. He waits. Anxious silence.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know all this, because I know everything. The Cholulans stand in fear and in awe: this man is surel  56. Forget the screen. A dozen soldiers move to fill the last When Cortes sees this is accomplished:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sadly, you leave us little choice. We are going to kill you now, all of you, in rightful punishment. The Cholulans blink in disbelief - A few turn helplessly toward the gates, but most are simp bewildered, in shock. No one moves. Everyone watches Cortes. He looks slowly over the whole square... The Cholulans contemplate their imminent death... Beat. Cortes nods. Gunfire, screams, shouts...but we see only Cortes. A drop flies onto his armor. Then another. MORE. He's getting spattered. As the sounds of the massacre become intolerable, they fa Two drops hit Cortes' face, and he closes his eyes. Seren face...or perhaps denial. A long silent beat...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was war. We did what we did. Marina and Father Olmeda are also getting splattered with

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whatever else you say the strategic value of this massacre was enormous. Again we appeared to have read the native mind, and we displayed a wrath so awesome it seemed Godlike. Without opening his eyes, Cortes turns toward Father Olme

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If we can convert _one more Indian, save one more soul from damnation, then this will have been - (justified)  57.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: You truly believe that?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I have to or I would go mad. (a terrible look crosses his face) Don't test me, father. Don't mock me. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fork in the road. Martin Lopez is adding Mexico to his

dialogues.speaker: MAP
dialogues.text: (See Next Page.) FORK IN ROAD. Next to Cortes is a palanquin, containing an AZTEC PRINCE gesturing..

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He says Moctezuma is embarrassed. We were right to attack the Cholulans, since they ignored Moctezuma's wishes and plotted against us.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Does Moctezuma think I'm stupid? (beat, re: the Prince) What's he selling me now? The Aztec Prince is indicating that the left fork is pref Cortes smiles politely to the Prince and proceeds down th the right. As they go:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Aztec Prince) You must tell me, since you are a noble lord, what the Great Moctezuma is like. The Aztec Prince replies: MARINA ; "I have never seen his face."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army slogs along a windy mountain trail. Ahh for the home fire...  58.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Remember now the furor Columbus' discoveries had caused throughout the civilized world... Though we were on this bleak trail for many reasons - to grow rich, to grow famous, to die young - still there was one desire which touched us all. We wanted to look over the mountain. We wanted to see the exotic new world. Behind Cortes, Marina is riding beside Sandoval. Her mann formal, reserved. She simply wants the information:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Can you tell me something?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: I will try.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I know the love some mothers feel for their children, but what is this other love you Spaniards speak of?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Between a man and w-woman?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Yes, is it desire?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: (the expert) More than that. It is pure.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Like love of your God?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: No, no. It makes you feel kind of crazy and weak and -

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: It sounds like a sickness.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Not at all. It's just... Well: You know it when you have it! (beat ) Do you l-love Cortes?! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Please try again later, to explain.  59. They're cresting a hill. Cortes turns back toward them an

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Are you giving her ideas?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: No, sir. A change comes over Sandoval's face.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then what's wrong? Sandoval tries to speak, can't. Blinks. Shakes his head. Cortes suddenly realizes: Sandoval sees something. Cortes whirls - The Valley of Mexico stretched below them: A spectacular city filled with huge stone buildings, buil water, connected to land by long causeways. It seems like enchanted vision. "I do not know how to describe this fir of things never heard of, seen, or dreamed of before." Th magical realm, a kingdom from our fantasies. The faces of the Spaniards are filled with awe. Over the center of the city, one large bird-of-prey cuts in the azure sky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Army moving along one of the dikes. Every structure - houses, towers, pyramids - is crowded w Likewise the lakes are darkened by swarms of canoes fille Indians straining for a glimpse of these pale, outlandish strangers. The welcome is powerful and eerie. Not warm, not triumpha certainly not cold and antagonistic. It is wary. The inex native faces heighten the feeling that we have entered an universe. Floating on the lake are fairy islands of flowers. These islands undulate as the water rises and falls. The causeway itself is only nine yards wide, crowded with and broken occasionally by bridges. One of Xicotencatl's Sons, at Cortes' side, points to a b

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: "These are easily removed. Soon we will be trapped inside their city."  60.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (nods) They must wonder why we look so confident. In the distance, the royal palanquin, blazing with burnis approaches. It is borne by nobles and bears a canopy of g work, powdered with jewels and fringed with silver. Cortes descends from his horse. He puts on his helmet, topped with a plume of feathers. The canopied bier stops and slowly MOCTEZUMA descends. Though we saw him at the opening of the film, in darkness glimpse did not prepare us for the spectacle we now witne He is magnificently clad, in a turquoise robe studded wit jewels, gold sandals, and spectacular feathered headdress strew the ground with cotton tapestry, so his imperial fe touch the soil. Everyone around him except the most prominent nobles has lowered: they cannot look at the "Great Speaker." On either side of Moctezuma are princes: CUITLAHUA and CU The CAMERA FOCUSES on one, then the other:

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Two great Princes flanked Moctezuma. His brother, Cuitlahua, had sworn to be our enemy and would have caused great harm had he not died of smallpox brought by one of our soldiers. The Emperor's nephew, Cuauhtemoc, vowed he would achieve our extinction. For most of us, he kept his word. Cuauhtemoc, only 25, has about him a sense of assurance a usually reserved for those of far greater age. His featur delicate, and very grave. Moctezuma himself is 40 years old, handsome, tall. His ha and straight, his beard thin, his complexion rather light with dignity, and there is great intelligence in his eyes

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Moctezuma had ruled for 17 years. Once the fiercest of warriors, he was now a deeply religious man. He knew, from his reports and his oracles, that one way or another we were to be his fate. The two leaders stare at each other. They bow.  61. There is a long and magnificent silence. This moment - th two such sophisticated, and yet wildly different, civiliz unique in human history. Both sides simply stare in wonde Finally the frozen moment is broken as the Princes around with seeming reluctance, touch the ground, then bring the their chests and heads.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Their hearts and minds welcomed us. Cortes takes out a necklace of glass beads and puts it ar Moctezuma's neck. It looks crude and plain next to the Az Then Cortes starts to embrace Moctezuma, but the other Az rush forward and stop him. Cortes nods and steps back. Moctezuma speaks. Marina begins to translate. Toward the speech her voice FADES SOFTER as simultaneous SUBTITLES c Eventually her voice stops altogether, though her physica tells us she is still translating.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA/MARINA
dialogues.text: O Lord, our Lord, you have arrived in this land, your land, your own city of Mexico, to sit on your mat your stool, which I have guarded for you. Your vassals, the old kings, my ancestors, are gone. Would that one of them could rise from the dead astonished and see what my eyes truly see, for in no dream do I see your face. Ah, these days, five, ten, a string of days, I have been anxious, watching for you, waiting to see you appear from your hidden place among the clouds and mists. For I was told you would appear, you would return to sit on your mat, your stool, and it is come true. Welcome and rest. Rest now. Rest in your palace. With your lords and companions, take your rest. Moctezuma grasps Cuitlahua's hand, turns and walks toward Cuauhtemoc takes Cortes' hand, and they follow. Cuauhtemoc is seething. Marina walks at Cortes' side:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Moctezuma's greeting is warm. The Great Speaker seems to see you as the fulfillment of the ancient prophecy, the return of the Quetzalcoatl.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And the others?  62.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They are more...cautious. Cortes glances at the angry Cuauhtemoc.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: That's an understatement. The CAMERA RISES slightly so that we see how small the Sp looks compared to the Indian population, and the magnific city. As the Spaniards file past, Cristobal, ever paranoid, say Alvarado:

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: God help us to leave here alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shadow of a giant PYRAMID (or cue), Moctezuma gest Cortes, indicating his own spectacular palace of silicate alabaster, surrounded by ponds and gardens.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: This is his palace. We are to stay in the palace of his father. He leads the Spanish procession into the building next do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceilings are carved cedar, the walls hung with cotton tapestries. Moctezuma leads Cortes by the hand into a

dialogues.speaker: GREAT HALL
dialogues.text: A cotton mat ornamented with gold and jewels is draped ov Moctezuma gestures for Cortes to sit.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Your old mat, your familiar stool. Cortes sits. Moctezuma nods in quiet contentment. The attitude of the other Aztecs tells us: they have neve seen anyone sit there. Moctezuma gestures and PORTERS enter bearing trays of foo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With hostile civility, Cuauhtemoc leads Cortes and his hi through gardens which are far less formal, but no less be than the French gardens Louis XIV would create 175 years

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next day Moctezuma's nephew, Cuauhtemoc, gave us a tour of Aztec wonders. At first we thought it an act of hospitality. Fruit trees. Borders of trellises supporting aromatic shrubs and creep Riotous washes of pink and purple and lavender; subtle sh delight the eye and nourish the soul. Fields of exotic', orchids: not hot-house creations but h flowers dancing gaudily into the distance. Cuauhtemoc does not speak, and there is no need. The magi reality washes over us. A jattice of reeds covered with blooming flowers marks ou into the

dialogues.speaker: AVIARY
dialogues.text: Cardinals, quetzales, endless species of parrots, humming Cuauhtemoc is completely at home: as if he too were a bir Marina (present, as always, whenever we see Moctezuma or Aztecs) seems to share this sense of peace. The Spaniards Cortes is restless, looking around... He squints. Points

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What's that there? Cuauhtemoc does not even glance where Cortes is pointing. Moctezuma, his words are SUBTITLED.

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: A golden eagle. The GOLDEN EAGLE has an individual perch high over the ot

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why is it kept separate?

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: Our city was built here because my ancestors saw an omen on the lake: a_golden eagle with a serpent in its talons, its wings spread wide to the rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuauhtemoc walks on, as if he wants to change the subject this, Cortes lingers:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: A magnificent bird.

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: We see fewer and fewer alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We suddenly realize: this is the same breed as the one wh carcass was brought to Moctezuma in the pre-credit sequen Leaving the aviary, we enter a

dialogues.speaker: ZOO
dialogues.text: Pumas, ocelots, alligators, etc. When we Gacrifice our enemies, we feed the torsos to these beasts. A casual and gracefully delivered threat. Cortes nods and follows Cuauhtemoc toward the: SNAKE CAGES. Various vipers, moccasins, coral snakes... Cuauhtemoc watches keenly for Cortes' reaction.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I don't like snakes. Marina does not translate this. Cortes looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: The God Quetzalcoatl, in spirit form, is half-bird, half-snake. Cortes looks into a cage with two RATTLESNAKES.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Open the cage. Marina translates. Cuauhtemoc orders it, and the cage is opened. Cortes enters. One of the snakes is asleep, the other looks at him waril

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: The most dangerous of vipers. Cortes takes a step forward.  65. The snake starts to rattle.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This noise is a warning - Cortes freezes. Not a muscle twitching. The snake moves its head side to side, watching him... Cuauhtemoc observing... Cortes' immobility calms the snake. Then Cortes moves. Perversity? The snake rattles furiously - Cortes throws his handkerchief - The snake strikes - At the handkerchief. Cortes strolls calmly out of the cage. Cuauhtemoc looks back and forth between Cortes and the sn quite sure what he's just witnessed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge buildings on every side. The tour has stopped beside round stone covered with markings.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Even now, 50 years later, this stone crammed with symbols of knives, houses, and rabbits, is the most accurate calendar on earth. They walk forward, toward the giant pyramid. Beside the cue stands a small building: its painted entra dragon's mouth with sharp fangs that drip blood. The Spaniards stare through the door/mouth and see: stack skulls. Cuauhtemoc smiles, speaks:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He says there are 136,000 skulls. AS many as 50,000 have been sacrificed in a single year. The Spaniards stand transfixed with horror.  66. Cuauhtemoc gestures and they begin to climb the cue. Cuau below, staring after them with undisguised contempt. Moct for the Spaniards at the top.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We realized: this tour had been a warning. If we were not Gods, we should know we were dealing with an advanced - and lethal - civilization. As they climb the cue, something is thrown off the top. The Spaniards exchange looks: What was that? After a moment, the distant action is repeated: a human b ripped open and dripping blood, sails down the steps...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Down below, butchers carve the bodies. Arms and legs are served to warriors, the rest to the lions. Cortes shoots a glance at Father Olmeda.

dialogues.speaker: TOP OF THE PYRAMID
dialogues.text: Cortes and his men arrive, breathless. Moctezuma greets t

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Welcome, Malinche, to the holy place. He leads them to a large convex stone with leather straps corners. It is covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is our sacrificial stone. He indicates a brazier with five still-beating hearts.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And here we make our offerings.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Great Moctezuma, I can contain myself no longer. I must tell you... We see Moctezuma's face as he listens, and Cortes' voice

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Our Captain calmly stated our mission: to convert the natives to Christianity. He also explained the Trinity and other mysteries which we accept on faith. Cortes' voice fades up again:  67.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: So that ours is the one true God. Moctezuma nods.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Malinche, I am sure your God is good to you. So are ours, to us. I o not ask you to forsake your beliefs. Please give to our people, and our Gods, the same respect. Cortes glances at the brazier -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear what I said?! This is an abomination!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER. OLMEDA
dialogues.text: (quietly, calmly) Not now, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: These "Gods" are devils! As Cortes raises his voice to the Emperor, several Aztec as if to seize him. Moctezuma motions for them to desist.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let us place our Virgin here and pee how your false Gods shrink from er! As Marina translates, Moctezuma shakes his head sadly, an for his guests to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: I_have committed a grave sacrilege in bringing you here. These Gods make the sun shine, the rain fall and the corn grow. I must now atone for exposing them to such blasphemy. He walks away, into one of two large temples. Cortes wants to pursue him, but Father Olmeda lays a calm the Captain's shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: "No use to overturn the alter if the idol remains enthroned in the heart." Father Olmeda leads Cortes away.  68.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That night we pondered Cortes' blunder. Would Moctezuma see that we could not be their Gods if we defiled their Gods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clouds of incense roll toward the ceiling. Spectacular ta cover the walls. On the floor, beautiful gifts are laid o of palm leaf. Moctezuma and Cortes sip cold cocoa.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
