dialogues.text: Despite Cortes' outburst, Moctezuma received us with great courtesy, toasting our Captain with frothy cocoa drinks. He asked jokingly to see the machines said to spew thunder and lightening. A Page places a thick piece of wood against the wall. Velasquez de Leon fires his gun into it. Moctezuma is amazed and scared and tries to conceal his f

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Cortes skirted questions of religion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is being cleared of Aztec articles and converted chapel. Crucifixes of several sizes litter the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Except to ask, most politely, if we could construct a chapel in our own quarters. Soldiers remove a large animal skin from the wall. Father Olmeda stares at what is revealed: A small doorway, plastered over. Father Olmeda runs his hand along the plaster: fresh.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: Fetch Cortes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LATER
dialogues.text: The plaster around the doorway is gone. Velasquez de Leon inserts his sword and pries off the cov It falls. Sandoval approaches with a burning torch and glances at C Cortes nods. Sandoval goes through the doorway - INT. TREASURE ROOM. Like a vision from some fairy tale: gold in nuggets and d grains, semi-precious stones (turquoise, jade, onyx, opal exquisite plates and metalwork combining these riches tog and piles of everything. This is El Dorado.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We later learned: this wealth represented 100 years of Aztec rule. When I saw it, I knew there was nothing to compare in all the world. The eyes of the Spaniards are wide with greed. Cortes' Pa rapid calculations in his notebook. Cortes is lost in reverie, fingering gold dust. Suddenly he realizes Father Olmeda's eyes are on him. He blinks - Looks up -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Am I a good Christian, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: Good Christians don't do this work. He says it gently, about Cortes...but his fatalistic tone it may apply equally to himself. Cortes lays the jewels down and leaves the room. After a moment, the others follow.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Touch nothing. Board it up as before, and put the alter in front. As the men move the large alter toward the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eerie background music. AZTEC NOBLES watch: Spanish soldiers wager greedily with cards made from drum Other Spaniards stand guard.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For the next days, they watched us. The behavior of the Spanish gamblers seems crude, uncivil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Spanish Soldier exits a public toilet built of reeds an

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Mexicans, whose obsession with cleanliness extended to daily bathing and public latrines, were curious if our excrement, like that of the Gods, was gold. As the Soldier walks away, several Young Aztecs run into toilet to examine what has been left. They exit, holding their noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royal entertainment: Dancers, spectacular foot-jugglers.. But the two leaders seem edgy: Moctezuma smiles at Cortes and nods. Cortes replies in the same way. Too formal. Long beat. Moctezuma glances to one side. Cortes follows the glance: The fierce and warlike Cuauhtemoc is cracking tiny nuts w teeth and eating them. Cortes exchanges looks with Sandoval and Velasquez De Leo is coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes lying in bed beside Marina. Eyes open, worrying. S loud knock at the door. Velasquez De Leon enters, followe Cristobal, Alvarado, Sandoval.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Captain? I'm sorry to...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: A messenger just arrived from Vera Cruz. Aztecs there have killed 20 of our shipmates. Cortes nods. Stares. Looks around at the others.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We must act.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Decisively.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes. Tomorrow we must save ourselves... or die in the attempt. (long beat) This is what I propose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and a dozen men cross the square to Moctezuma's pa

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning will seem the same as today. A group of us will go to Moctezuma's chambers. As always, we will be fully armed. After the first dozen, a second casually follows. Then a

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For the first time, other soldiers will follow. We must hope they attract no particular notice.  72. The last two groups loiter outside Moctezuma's palace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spaniards enter, and Moctezuma nods graciously.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then, when we enter, I will -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (LIVE)
dialogues.text: Great Moctezuma, I must demand - Moctezuma stops him with a gesture. He proceeds playfully

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Malinche, is this true that of the riches I give your King, he will receive only a fifth?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes, but -

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: And_you receive an equal fifth? Cortes nods. Moctezuma proceeds with mock outrage:

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the rest is divided among your men?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: It's true. Moctezuma stares gravely at Cortes and then bursts out la

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: You're a very clever man! He continues to laugh. No one joins him. He realizes there is tension in the air. Nods gravely.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have heard about 20 of your men?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: I_hear it too, with shame and sadness. I have come to think of you as my brother, and to show my eart has good will...  73. He motions and a gorgeous princess, DONA ANA, appears.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I_am giving you today my third daughter, to be one of your wives. For a moment Cortes is thrown off course, both by the act generosity and the luminous beauty of this girl.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: She is very beautiful... Marina dutifully translates this...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that does not change what happened. There have been too many accidents. Until those who killed my men can be brought here and questioned, you yourself must come with us, to our quarters. He watches Moctezuma's face as Marina translates. Bewilderment, then shock, then outrage. Moctezuma's eyes flash toward his GUARDS - Because they have their eyes lowered, they do not see him As his mouth opens, Velasquez de Leon and Cristobal appro swords drawn. There is nothing Moctezuma_ can do. He is trapped. He lowers his eyes. His body trembles with rage.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Go...as your prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: As our guest.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Is this how my kindness is rewarded? (anger ) When did a great prince such as myself, ever leave his palace to stay with strangers?!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You will hold court there, as always. Everything will be the same. Moctezuma stares at Cortes.  74.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Even if I should consent to such a degradation, my subjects never would. I remain here.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Then let the barbarian die! Now! Beat. Moctezuma looks at Marina. Marina looks at Cortes: translate? He nods, and she translates. Moctezuma stares at Cortes. Expressionless, but thinking. Finally he smiles. And stands. Paradoxically, he seem str imperious... He gestures toward the door

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Let _us go then to the palace of my father and see what destiny awaits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moctezuma walks, escorted, across the square to Axayacatl

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Cortes warned that our victory was temporary. We would still have to fight the Aztecs, and the conflict would be savage, and soon. Moctezuma's posture is straight, proud, bewildering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: young Bernal Diaz sits making marks on an Aztec scroll us pencil. Cortes walks by. Stops. Looks. Looks again.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DIAZ
dialogues.text: Making notes. So I can remember

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: For what purpose? YOUNG DIAZ . So I can tell my grandchildren.  75. Cortes stares at him. Not with thought, but with a kind o realization. A mystical moment.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No. So you can tell the world. (long beat) That is, if you live. He laughs and walks away. Young Diaz looks after him, then looks down again at his now he's looking at them in a different way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moctezuma on his mat stroking his python. Surrounding him PAPAS. In the center is a statue of a grotesque Aztec God

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We kept our word. Outwardly nothing changed except the location of Moctezuma's court. Across the vast room, Cortes chats with Sandoval as Marin Something about the posture of the Aztecs, their ritualiz and attitudes, is dissonant, unsettling, impenetrable. A interrupts their conference, and Moctezuma glares at him. The Servant says something more, and Moctezuma's expressi He nods. In response, ANOTHER PAPA enters, carrying a dead golden When he sees this, Moctezuma growls fiercely and the ente retreats. Simultaneously: Cuauhtemoc rises and begins to Cortes turns to Marina:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What's going on? She shakes her head, watching intently as: Cuauhtemoc argues with considerable passion.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't possibly hear them. She makes no reply, watches: Moctezuma gestures, and Cuauhtemoc bows, starts for the d

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They are taught perfect elocution. You can read their lips. (without pause) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MoctezunMARINQPRENT 'Bdauhtemoc, just begged the Emperor to kill us.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Moctezuma listened?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He had to. Cuauhtemoc is a potential heir to the throne.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: to Sandoval) Follow Cuauhtemoc and arrest him. Sandoval starts after Cuauhtemoc, motioning to SEVERAL SO accompany him. Cuauhtemoc is still visible down the long we see the Spaniards quickly closing in for the arrest. Cortes looks at Marina...hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I'm going to sleep with Moctezuma's daughter tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: She is young and pretty.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You're not jealous?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Don't insult me. Cortes looks her over as if for the first time: profound

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You are remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: No. But I am here first, and I will bear your child. He stares.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Oh. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: You're not happy?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I'm always happy. He doesn't look it. He realizes some other response is required.  77.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I am proud to have you as the mother of my child. (intense, to himself) May it be a son! Hardly the reaction she wanted. As she swallows her disap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aztecs watch in bewilderment as Spaniards pile wood and w (spears, arrows, lances) in the center of the square.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A few days later, those who killed 20 of our men were brought to Tenochtitlan. Seventeen bound Aztecs are led out of Axayacatl's Palace the top of the wood pile.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: According to Cortes, they said they were acting on Moctezuma's orders. The Aztecs claimed we misunderstood. As Mexican pedestrians look on in astonishment, Moctezuma a balcony in shackles. His eyes are lowered in shame. The pyre is lit. The condemned men start to burn. Moctezuma watches... Cortes steps to Moctezuma's side. Moctezuma senses him, but does not look at him.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: So...you_ sacrifice your enemies after all. Cortes blinks.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I_was talking to your priest. He tells me your God commanded Abraham to sacrifice his son Isaac. (finally looks at Cortes) And was not Jesus himself sacrificed by your God?  78. Hold on Cortes' reaction -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and Moctezuma play an Aztec dice game, throwing sm pellets and slabs across the room. The two men seem cheer relaxed, the best of friends.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Moctezuma was unchained after the burnings, and he was different. Was he hiding something? Waiting? He seemed to have a hidden faith that somehow his Gods would release him from this indignity. A brief pause in the game. We catch Moctezuma staring at look on his face is completely inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and Marina walking, with Cristobal and Alvarado be The streets are crowded with Indians who keep glancing in direction, as if waiting for something.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We enjoyed the city. We relaxed. And every time we did, we saw something that chilled our hearts.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I don't think there is - or should be - any limit to the number of women a man can have. In Arabia - They stop. A noise. A procession approaching. The Aztecs around them start to weep.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: What? What is it? The Spaniards group together, watching as: Six Children are borne through the streets. They are weep profusely. The Aztec pedestrians are weeping with equal abandon.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They believe the tears of the children bring rain, so the crops will grow.  79.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Then...this is theatre?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: No. The children are sacrificed. All the Spaniards stare in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Aztec clowns are putting on a raucous performance... Moctezuma in full finery, sits on his mat next to Cortes. of his hand he dismisses the clowns and turns to Cortes.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Now. I have a surprise for you. He motions again, and AZTEC PRINCES come forward and prof

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: What you asked. Our chiefs are declaring loyalty to King Carlos. The line of chiefs goes on across the room and out the do riches they hold are staggering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The treasure room door has been reopened, and Spanish tro bringing out the booty. Fully displayed, it is even more Cortes' Page is noting everything, with its value, in a b

dialogues.text: Moctezuma also told us of the secret treasure room and freely gave us its contents. Some of the loot is being carried through the room, out o

dialogues.speaker: A LARGE ROOF TERRACE
dialogues.text: Where the stones are being removed from the exquisite gol and the gold melted down into ingots.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We melted down their jewelry, so the gold would be easier to transport.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moctezuma and Cortes sit on mats examining the treasure a piled before them. Again Cortes' Page takes notes. DIAZ (V.0. Perhaps Moctezuma hoped if we had all his wealth we would go home. Moctezuma watches as Cortes argues quietly with Velasquez

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: But why?! We've conquered Mexico! Their power, revenues, and doyalty have been given us without a single blow being struck!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Do we seek only power, riches? (turning to Moctezuma) My Lord, there is one more thing I must ask.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: I_will grant it.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: My men are not content with our chapel. We beg permission to remove your Gods from the top of the pyramid and put our Lady in their place. Moctezuma stares at Cortes.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Do you love war? Cortes is taken aback -

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My Gods and my people will rise.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Even one temple might do. Besides...we will take it regardless of your answer. Moctezuma stares at Cortes...

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: (measured, a threat) Then I give my permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes stares up at Huitzilopochtli, the fat Aztec war Go cheeks, terrible eyes, girdled with hissing snakes. Cortes extends his hand. An iron bar is placed in it

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Make it clean. He leaps onto the idol and begins SMASHING it. This is no demolition. This is RAGE. FURY. MADNESS. At first others join in, but the pace and intensity of th assault distracts them. They stop and stare. At Father Olmeda's side, Velasquez de Leon shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: Yes. This goes beyond faith.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Perhaps...the slaughter in Cholula, burning those people alive... Does he feel some remorse?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: No. This is about his greatness. Cortes' anger is both scary and awe-inspiring...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If he truly had faith, he would accept himself as a gift from God.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: At least we kill and eat our enemies... even our selves...but not our Gods! He laughs derisively and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see: the square filled with protest incited by a group of Papas. Drawing back inside:  83. Moctezuma sits surrounded by enraged Priests. His attitud posture tell us that his power has returned. On the mat in front of him is a pile of green wilted corn

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: The Gods are outraged. The People are in arms. Leave at once, or you will die.

dialogues.speaker: CORT
dialogues.text: My Lord, we would be pleased to go, but have no means. As you know, our ships were rotten and had to be sunk.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: (smiles) But _- how lucky - new ships have arrived! He unfolds an Aztec scroll which shows several large vess

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spaniards! Cortes stares at the scroll.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Blessed be the Redeemer for his mercies. Can you tell, from this scroll, how many men have come?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Thirteen hundred.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And who is their leader?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: A man named "Narvaez." Cortes stares at Moctezuma...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If you knows his name, then your men made contact with him. Moctezuma stares at Cortes, and then, very slowly, smiles

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What sort of contact? Beat. Moctezuma is now confident, imperial again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The God Smoking Mirror loves to play tricks on us all. INT. CORTES ROOM. NIGHT. A conference of the chief hidalgos.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Narvaez is sent by my cousin Velasquez to quell our mutiny. (off Cortes' look) But we are right to mutiny. History is on our side.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Screw history. Narvaez has fresh men, fresh horses -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: And if Moctezuma is in contact with him, they must have made a deal.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes. Moctezuma has waited patiently, with great confidence, for the tide to shift. And now it has. (long beat) We have only one advantage. (off their looks) They both expect us to lose.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: That's an advantage?!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We leave tonight. Alvarado will remain in charge of the garrison. will take 70 men to the sea. EXT. ROAD. NIGHT. Fast and forced march. Only it isn't a "march." The men are running. EXT. ROAD. DAY. Foot soldiers trotting, the five horses walking.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A_ foot soldier, tiring, pats the leg of a horseman, and places.  85.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Speed was our only ally, surprise our only weapon. Suddenly the company stops, peers into: a deep ravine. Th both directions: the ravine finally closes miles away...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: Horses can be round in an hour, but those on foot will lose half a day. Cortes shakes his head; no good. He stares at the ravine: wide, no way to cross it...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Send the horses on. The others look at him skeptically. He addresses Sandoval

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go. Sandoval kicks his horse, and the other four ride after h

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: But how do we cross?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: You don't - (know?! Are you crazy?!)

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Some kind of bridge?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: But what would we make it of? Again Cortes looks up and down the ravine.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Maybe the bridge is already here...

dialogues.speaker: A HUNDRED YARDS AWAY
dialogues.text: They stare at a huge sycamore tree five feet in diameter.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: With swords? It would take half a day to cut it down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes shakes his head: Cristobal doesn't get it." Then Cristobal follows Cortes' gaze...up into the branche tree:  86. A hundred feet off the ground, the branches approach thos sister tree from the other side of the ravine. Cristobal gives Cortes a look: are you criminally insane?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Volunteers? None. Just as he expected. He starts to climb the tree.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: You're not scared of heights?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No. Ts falling from heights I don't ike. MINUTES LATER. Cortes climbing quickly... Too quickly. He grabs a branch where wet leaves are resti Loses his grip - Plunges six feet, landing on another branch with terrific almost falling to his death. He lies there. Heaves a big sigh. Calls to those below:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Just a few ribs. Starts to climb again. As he does, the wind comes up, and the branches begin to Down below, Cristobal watches with Velasquez de Leon:

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: If he falls, we can return to Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: To hell with Cuba!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cristobal looks surprised at his vehemence.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop your whining. You have five women, a fortune in gold, and you're having the time of your life.  87.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: True enough. (beat ) But I can complain if I want to.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: looking up) Holy Mother of God... Cortes nears the top. Ties a rope to the tree he's in. The wind is strong. The pinnacle swaying back and forth.. approaching the sister tree, then pulling away... Approaching...pulling away... Cortes has to make his leap at precisely the right instan He's terrified. Prepares to leap, then stops himself. Rea

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If you're scared, you'll fall. He takes a deep breath. Looks down at the others. Waves. Grins. This is not a moment for sanity. He looks back at the waving trees.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell. Rope tied to his waist, he rocks with the tree, preparing Velasquez de Leon crosses himself. Cortes SCREAMS at the top of his lungs, LEAPS - Fails to catch his branch - Falls... Grabs another branch which breaks his fall, but can't hol Falls again and finally latches on, two hands gripping ti white, sick grimace on his face. He closes his eyes with relief: made it.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: The rope is now strung from the top of the first tree to landed in the second, so that others can traverse the rav jumping. The last man, Cristobal, moves gingerly across..  88.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Hurry, the horses! Dust in the distance. 100 YARDS AWAY. MINUTES LATER. As the horses ride up, the foot soldiers wait directly ac where Sandoval left them. The sycamore trees sway in the Sandoval stops...stares...looks around dumfounded...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We flew. Sandoval nods. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ' CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go. The horses walk, the men trot.

dialogues.text: Tents sitting in the rain.

dialogues.text: We reached the sea in 23 hours and sent on Father Olmeda and Martin Lopez, posing as messengers bearing a letter of conciliation. We hoped to thus distract Narvaez from our purpose. The rain is savage. Most tents are dark, but one is well- Approaching the doorway... INT. CORTES' TENT. NIGHT. Cortes pacing anxiously, Sandoval enters, looking very worried.

dialogues.text: From Father Olmeda and -

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: No. From T-T-Tenoch -

dialogues.text: If it's bad news, say it  89.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Alvarado believed the Mexicans were about to attack. He struck first during one of their festivals, and slaughtered them. The entire city is now counter-attacking our garrison. Cortes stares at him thoughtfully...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Perhaps this was Moctezuma's plan, with Narvaez. Divide and conquer.

dialogues.speaker: __ SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: (quite concerned) W-w-what are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: calm, almost amused: ) Well... I guess we better defeat Narvaez, don't you think? leans back, closes his eyes Wake me when Father Olmeda an Martin Lopez return.

dialogues.text: How far is it? , MARTIN LOPEZ . Without rain, an hour's journey.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And now? They look out at the downpour: only fools would...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miserable march through thick rain. No trotting now. Cort Cristobal, and Sandoval walk in front.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: (to Sandoval) Yes. I had a cat once too... But it died.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: That's too bad, I -

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: I strangled it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: I had good reason. Cortes stops, falls to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What now?! Sandoval joins Cortes. Cristobal sees: The small cross erected when they left Cempoala.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: How could we find this? In the dark, the rain? He kneels too. Sandoval speaks their thought:

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Because Our Lord favors us.

dialogues.text: From every side, Cortes' men are firing into the air. Meanwhile: fireflies are blinking in the distance. Narvaez's men hear the musket shots, see the fireflies...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Narvaez' men mistook the blinking fireflies for our muskets and thought we had somehow mustered a huge force. Cortes and Sandoval, from opposite sides, are climbing th to-hand combat. They reach the top as a silhouette in a nightshirt runs f gut into the darkness and is attacked from two sides. He ace -  92.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: V-victory! V-victory for Cortes! Narvaez is dead! Down below, Cortes' men take up the chant: "Narvaez is de echoes across the camp.

dialogues.text: Cortes sits in an orange gown receiving homage from Narva He offers his hand imperiously for them to kiss.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Narvaez was not dead. His humiliation was completed in the morning when he saw our meager forces. Narvaez sits nearby. He is now wearing an eye patch.

dialogues.speaker: NARVAEZ
dialogues.text: Thank your evil luck for putting me into your power so easily.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I have much to be thankful for, but this is the least of my achievements. Cortes gives each of Narvaez' men a small sack. At_a mome one else is in hearing, Cortes explains to Sandoval:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The gold is to keep these mercenaries from having second thoughts. Nearby, two of Cortes' men - Villafana (a common soldier distinctive scar who we saw on the docks in Cuba) and his watch with barely concealed rage.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: But our own men have received nothing, These gifts will -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Exactly. (to Villafana and Cohort) What sort of soldiers follow a man like Narvaez? Do they fight for glory or God? No. Only for gold.  93.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: I am the same.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Good. You shall have the gold you dream of. (giving him _a_ small sack) Lots of it. And we shall use these (indicates Narvaez' men) cousins of ours to get it. A SOLDIER on horseback rides up furiously, hands Cortes a Sandoval watches as Cortes reads the message with grave c

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Our garrison?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The Aztecs stopped their attack. why? He rises, conceals his concern, and announces cheerfully:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men! Let us march to Tenochtitlan and show our recruits how much the Aztecs love us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expanded Spanish Army walking along a causeway. Like a neutron bomb landed: No Indians in sight. In the distance, a single canoe skims the water. Ominous. Cortes and Sandoval exchanged worried looks. Some of the bridges which connected other dikes have been Clear implication: the Spaniards will have to fight their

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: P-perhaps the last message we received was a trick? As they cross one of the bridges, a horse falls. The caravan stops. Cortes trots back to examine the animal. Leg broken, it w be destroyed. Botello, the exotic little man who was throwing tarot on mutters something. Cortes glowers in his direction:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What did you say?  94.

dialogues.speaker: BOTELLO
dialogues.text: I don't care if you hate me. I speak the truth. This is a bad omen.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: In a deserted city, you need a spastic horse to tell you something is wrong? Botello gestures derisively and retreats. Cortes stares at the horse.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shoot it. The order carried out. Cortes looks anxiously toward Tenochtitlan. Silence... Cortes begins to fidget... He and Sandoval exc another look... Finally we hear a shot fired in reply. Cortes spurs his horse and they move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and his men enter. The square is empty except FOUR MEXICA, each standing in dripping blood. Cortes and company look at the Mexica with mounting horro realize: The reason they drip blood is because they are wearing th slaughtered men. Cortes turns to Marina:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: This is intended to scare us?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: No. It's one of their rituals. The Ceremony of the Flayed Men. Cortes nods. Stares again at the four men... Barely overcoming his horror, he kicks his horse and move Alvarado rushes out to meet him.  95.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: How are your troops?

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: No food. No water. Moctezuma is approaching. Cortes dismounts and walks right past him. On Moctezuma's face: rage, then sadness, confusion; and a

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Is this the reward I get for calling off my men and preventing the slaughter of yours?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You prefer to kill us slowly, cutting off food and water?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: I_am helpless to change these things when I am your captive.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Aren't you the Great Moctezuma? Long beat. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: If you wish our markets reopened you must release my nephew Cuauhtemoc.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: He hates all Spaniards.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: He is married to my youngest daughter, he is in line for the throne, and he will obey the emperor. Cortes considers this, finally turns to De Leon:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Order it done. (stares at Moctezuma...) When I was gone, why did you save my men? (off Moctezuma's stare) You feared for your life?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: The greatest honor for a warrior is to die in combat. May that be my fate.  96.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then why?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Because you Cortes, are a most remarkable. ..being. It seems an unequivocal statement of admiration and awe.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I_wanted to make sure you came back. He smiles, with an ominous hint of triumph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvarado talking as Cortes stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: ...our spies said they were planning to attack, so I struck first... Cortes watches as Cuauhtemoc is released from the Spanish walks across the square. As Cuauhtemoc passes TWO WOMEN, they lower their eyes def They will not look at his face. Cortes frowns: what does this mean?

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: So you see? I had no choice.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (whirls) Choice?! This was their festival, during which they NEVER wage war!

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: I caught them by surprise -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: They outnumber us a thousand to one! The one thing you were not to do was provoke their wrath!

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You are a great soldier, Alvarado, with the brain of a crustacean. When we return to battle, you will fight in the most precarious position.  97.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: grins) Sounds good to me.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Get out of here! Alvarado leaves. Cortes stares after him. Then he looks again out the wind Cuauhtemoc no longer visible. Just a few Aztecs...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should have left Velasquez de Leon in charge. We think he's talking to an empty room.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's the only man I have who's not a child. Marina approaches him. At her touch, his speech becomes g affectionate.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But the children are so simple. (glance after Alvarado) One must never blame them for being themselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: What worries you?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (scornful) Worried? (stops... thinks...) That I've led them all to slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diaz, the Young Soldier who planted the orange pips, lies his bedroll, fully armed. His face peaceful, almost innoc

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Even when this campaign was over, I always slept on the floor, in my clothes. I grew used to it, and for ears after I never lay down ina ed unless there was a woman in it. A commotion nearby; soldiers run and shout. Diaz does not  98. A flaming arrow pierces the air and lands on Young Diaz' bursts into flames. He leaps up and stamps it out. Around him, other soldiers jump to arms -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cortes and Marina approach, Moctezuma stands watching and stroking his python...

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: It is my shame I am here with you and not there, leading my people.

dialogues.speaker: _ CORTES
dialogues.text: Who is the warrior who leads them?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: (knowing the answer) Where? Cortes points to a dynamic Chieftain exhorting his troops

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't recognize my nephew Cuauhtemoc, who you just released?!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You told me he would open the markets.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: He has. To our people.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: You said he would obey the emperor.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: He_ does. As of now, he is the emperor. Enraged, Cortes stalks out of the room -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaniards burst out of Axayacatl's palace and are quickly by TZILACATZIN, a giant Aztec slingshot artist, and other

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Moctezuma's gentle manners had not prepared us for this battle. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow to 9HAS6CONReDAztecs were even more difficult to pacify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaming arrows, Indians leaping through windows, smoke so can hardly see. Guns fire, swords slice the air; a vision

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They suffered great casualties, but when we sued for peace, they told us 25,000 of their number could die for every Spaniard and they would be content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Olmeda with Moctezuma. DIAZ (V.O. Their love of death terrified us so we appealed to Moctezuma to end the bloodshed.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: I_ desire only to die.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: (gently) But must all your people, and ours, die with you? Moctezuma stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Allow us to leave in peace, and we will never return. Long beat. Moctezuma stares at Father Olmeda.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: I_understand more than you think. Father Olmeda is about to question this enigmatic reply w Moctezuma rises slowly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battle rages. Cortes and Marina watch:  100. Moctezuma walks onto a rooftop, dressed in his official r loin cloth, mantle embroidered with feathers, gold decora turquoise ear plugs, a jade ornament piercing both nostri rock crystal tube piercing his lower lip. His face is bri painted. The effect is bizarre but quite beautiful) He's surrounded and protected by Spaniards. The Aztecs stop fighting, but their attitude toward Mocte changed: it's still respectful, but for the first time th directly at his face.

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: People, my people who I love, brave people, why are you fighting? To save me? I_am not a prisoner. I am already dead. Marina translating for Cortes...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Already..."dead?"

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Do you want to drive away the strangers? That is not necessary. If you let them go, the strangers will leave and never return. This is their word. They give their word. Should we not believe them?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What is he doing? What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: Have not the strangers always been honest and true? Go home, then, Take the word of these strangers and lay down your arms. Listen please. Listen to your emperor. He stops. His eyes search the crowd and find Cuauhtemoc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to Cuauhtemoc. Cortes sees it.

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: I am the Emperor now! Listen to me! This man is a coward! A rising swell of anger as other Aztecs shout similar ins is enraged at this carefully staged piece of theatre.  101.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (to Cortes) They are calling him a eunuch, an old woman, a sodomite for the white men. Cuauhtemoc fires an arrow at Moctezuma. Barely misses. Ot shoot arrows, throw stones, and hurl insults - Moctezuma stands proudly: accepting, even welcoming, the The Spaniards Guards, taken by surprise, rush to protect Moctezuma is hit on the chest by two stones - The giant Tzilacatzin fires his slingshot... And hits Moctezuma on the head. He drops -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish Guards hurriedly cover him up and carry him insid INT. PALACE. DAY. As Moctezuma is carried in, he is brought past a glaring Moctezuma looks up at him with a wan smile of triumph. He is then carried into the adjoining room. Cortes glares after him with homicidal fury, then follows the other room. The door closes slowly, ominously.. Hold on the door. In the b.g., we HEAR THE BATTLE RAGING.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: SAME DOOR, later. (BATTLE SFX, under.) Sandoval exits, an those who are waiting: SANDOVAL ; He's refusing all medical treatment.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: SAME DOOR, later. (BATTLE, under.) Velasquez De Leon exit

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: He's refusing all food.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: SAME DOOR, later. Cortes' Page emerges, downcast.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' PAGE
dialogues.text: Moctezuma is dead Others move forward: "What happened?", "What did he die o  102.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' PAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He refused the sacraments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes and Father Olmeda hover near Moctezuma's wheezing

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' PAGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cortes was with him to the end.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I beg you again, Great Speaker. (indicating Olmeda) Before your soul is damned -

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: No. My Gods have forsaken me, but I will not forsake them. Besides... He indicates Father Olmeda, who at the moment is examinin evident greed a beautiful gold necklace... When Cortes turns back, Moctezuma gives him his hand:

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Malinche... My daughters, sweet and fiery, are here with you. Will you protect them?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (touched) Of course. (hesitates, can't resist asking: ) And you, can you tell me... They sa you were once a great warrior to f Moctezuma's nod Why did you never fight us? Moctezuma smiles as if to say: Don't you know??

dialogues.speaker: MOCTEZUMA
dialogues.text: If_ you were a God, I dared not, If you were what you say, ambassador toa great King: What kind of King would I be if TI made war on an ambassador? (breathing more heavily...) Besides, we Mexica fight wars to gain captives. (gestures) Here in Tenochtitlan, are you not already our prisoner? Cortes stares at him, stunned...  103. Moctezuma smiles wanly... Cortes realizing suddenly: has Moctezuma_ already defeate Moctezuma's breath getting shorter and shorter... ANOTHER ANGLE. MOMENTS OR MINUTES LATER. The Page watches as: Cortes closes Moctezuma's eyes. INT. THE NEXT ROOM. As Cortes' Page finishes this story.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DIAZ
dialogues.text: Is that really what happened?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' PAGE
dialogues.text: Of course

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DIAZ
dialogues.text: But...when he left here, Cortes seemed enraged at Moctezuma...? Cortes' Page stares at Young Bernal Diaz with a peculiar and we realize: the Page's story may be a lie. Their attention is diverted by the sound of the raging ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a barricaded doorway, soldiers are firing, reloading, again without aiming their shotguns and crossbows: the In thickly massed the Spaniards can't miss. Botello the Soothsayer stands waiting as Cortes paces the listening to the anxious report of:

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: -handful of corn per day: Without food and clean water, we'll never last the week.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (turns to Botello) You were right about the horse's death.

dialogues.speaker: BOTELLO
dialogues.text: As always.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If I seek your counsel, am I no better than Moctezuma, whose world is cursed by superstition?  104.

dialogues.speaker: BOTELLO
dialogues.text: (snide) A pretty question, sir. Shall I consult the stars for an answer?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (irritable) What is your augury now? For us?

dialogues.speaker: BOTELLO
dialogues.text: Leave tomorrow night or die. Cortes nods thoughtfully and giances across the room, whe CARPENTERS are building some kind of contraption...

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: (supporting Botello) The Indians are still unprepared for night battle, so perhaps -

dialogues.speaker: BOTELLO
dialogues.text: It's not military tactics; it's fate.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (growls) Fate is something we cause, not submit to. Father Olmeda arches an eyebrow at Cortes...

dialogues.speaker: , CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With God's mercy, of course.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Battle raging. The front doors swing open, and FOUR MEXICAN PRINCES carr wrapped in turquoise cloth. The battle stops. The body is borne with great solemnity. Indian drums roll Soldiers on both sides stand silently in tribute. Even those Aztecs who cursed and threw stones now give Mo respect: let us forget failings and honor the dead.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Some say they gave Moctezuma's body royal honors; (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: others BIAZHEQNGURDed him into a canal like carrion. Either way, they claim we killed him with a sword thrust up his rectum. Moctezuma's body disappears slowly around a corner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge room where Moctezuma once held court is now the command room: Cortes and the other Hidalgos are diagrammi their departure. A Messenger is given final instructions, departs...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We had to flee. To camouflage our true intentions, we sent a message asking Cuauhtemoc for peace. Cortes' Page opens the door, and fifty Soldiers rush in. room is a pile: all the treasure the Spaniards have accum Soldiers dig greedily through these riches.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' PAGE
dialogues.text: In all, it is worth 700,000 pesos! Cortes says: Take what you can. But remember: he goes safest at night who travels lightest. The men scarcely hear him; they're stuffing their shirts gold ingots. Across the room, the war council continues:

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: But Cortes wants me in the most precarious place, which is the rear.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Then I must fight there too. (to Alvarado) With due respect: we cannot survive another error in judgement... Alvarado turns toward Cortes and smiles with defiant char

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Well? You're the Captain of the Captains. Cortes lowers his eyes and says sadly to Velasquez de Leo

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We gratefully accept your offer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men pack their bags and prepare for battle.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' PAGE
dialogues.text: Two hours to departure. Two hours... Alvarado's warming up like a boxer: shoving the wall, gru psyching himself up... gristobal holds hands with two of his WIVES as two others eet. Sandoval tests the blade of his sword. Velasquez De Leon sits in a corner. Cervantes (the blond Cortes found long ago sleeping on his watch) walks past -

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Hey! You! Cervantes!

dialogues.speaker: CERVANTES
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: I have no one to drink with me. Will you -

dialogues.speaker: CERVANTES
dialogues.text: (big grin) Shouldn't be a problem, sir. Velasquez de Leon hands Cervantes his bota (leather wineb Cervantes hoists it and sprays a stream into his mouth. O into his mouth; he spills some onto his armor...

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: The wine is Castilian. I've been nursing it the whole trip... Velasquez de Leon retrieves the bota and drinks himself. Lowers the bag...looks at Cervantes...

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you in the rear?

dialogues.speaker: CERVANTES
dialogues.text: Tonight's battle?! No sir. To be honest, I'm something of a coward, and I want to get out of here as quick as I can! Cervantes glances at the wine, hoping for another drink Velasquez de Leon hands him the bag.  107.

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: Could you carry this for me? You'll have a better chance of getting it through.

dialogues.speaker: CERVANTES
dialogues.text: No problem, sir. No problem at all. And I promise I will not touch another drop. On my honor! He bows obsequiously, and saunters away with the bota... Velasquez de Leon stares. His face - placid on the surfac sad underneath that we can't bear to look at it. We glide to where Villafana and his Cohort, who complaine Narvaez' men received gold, are whispering conspiratorial

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: On this night, most of us knew we could only survive united. But in the whole campaign we never took a step forward without being sabotaged from the rear. We're now close enough to overhear

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: ...we'll only reach Cuba if Cortes dies.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA'S COHORT
dialogues.text: You wouldn't strike at him? Villafana shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA'S COHORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even in battle?

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: Especially in battle. But in battle sometimes a man's virtues do him in... His Cohort is puzzled. As Villafana leans forward to expl

dialogues.text: Cortes sleeping, Marina gently rubbing his head. She stops, looks at him. He's spread out on the bed, shirt open, Indian feathers s around as if having been incorporated in their love-makin Something momentous in her stoic face...  108. She undoes her huipil and we see her rounded belly: five along, but very large... Slowly, solemnly, she ties his shirt-tail to the tail of She places his sleeping hand over the knot. Puts her own hand over his. (From this Aztec ritual comes "tie the knot.") Sandoval knocks, sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes to midnight Marina nods. While the unwitting "groom" slept through th "ceremony," the "bride's" face streams with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors swing silently open.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This was to be the most famous battle in our campaign. It came to be called "noche triste," the sad night. Two Spaniards exit, look around - The Square totally deserted. The Two Men motion, and 40 more emerge, carrying an enorm (the structure we saw being constructed)

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We chose the shortest causeway. The bridges had been removed, so we built a mobile one to carry from one section to the next. The platform is followed by foot soldiers, cavalry, women porters, the Tlascalan allies, and finally the rear guard Velasquez de Leon and Alvarado.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was dark. A fine mist obscured and muffled our departure. They enter the dike.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: By some miracle, or by ineptitude, the Aztecs had posted no guards. The portable bridge is put in place and they start across  109. The land seems such a short distance away... Suddenly we recognize the captive: Cervantes, the buffoon with the blond beard. Cuauhtemoc himself is everywhere: doing battle, directing Caciques, spreading the spirit of victory. CAMERA MOVES I Handsome, confident, full of fury; this man is a leader.  110.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Watching Cuauhtemoc, we were overcome by a sense of familiarity: he was Moctezuma's blood. He resembled Moctezuma. It was as if Moctezuma himself, Moctezuma the warrior, had finally come forth to fight us: in the form of Cuauhtemoc. Hold on Cuauhtemoc as this idea, this eerie resemblance, emotions. dialogues.text: For the second time, I knew I would die. We all knew it. I was hardly wrong. Young Diaz miraculously escapes, for the moment, from thr A few feet away, the giant Tzilacatzin pulls back his sli knocks a Spaniard off his horse. Two Spaniards fire crossbows at him - Hit him! Some Spaniards seem sluggish. When they run, it looks lik motion. When they hit the water, they sink. Either way th

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Those who had loaded themselves with gold this night fulfilled a life-long dream: they died rich. We see Villafana. Sneaky eyes.  111.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And even in such extremity, petty plots unfolded. Villafana is guarding Marina. But...is it possible?...he very subtly, guiding her away from safety: As we see this, Villafana's Cohort grabs Cortes' arm and something. Points at Marina. Cortes sees her. Her swollen belly. Swollen with his chil hesitation, he hurtles toward her, into the heart of the We realize: this is his virtue doing him in! In this moment, through the insane intensity of his rage, clearly how much Cortes loves his Indian mistress. And she knows it. Sees it. Though her features, as always impassive, it touches her to see Cortes' passion made man As Cortes frees her, they exchange a look. An acknowledge Then Villafana himself, watching Cortes, is seized from t dragged toward the water.
