Villafana scurries free as all the Mexicans concentrate o They grab his limbs, knock his sword to the ground - He yells, writhes, punches, but they're dragging him towa Tzilacatzin grabs him. Holds him aloft and laughs. Is everything lost? No. Cristobal De Olid is tearing toward Cortes. Like a tr steaming through heavy grass, he cuts a swath through the

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whatever you say of Cristobal de Olid, in battle he was a veritable Hector. It is strange, but I swear I never saw another man fight with such bravery. The sight of Cristobal - and certain death - forces Tzila drop Cortes - Cristobal throws Cortes a sword. Cortes fights as: Cristobal and Tzilacatzin begin a private battle of wills  112. Sandoval is also moving toward Cortes, bringing an extra An Aztec jabs at Cortes' head. Blood bursts forth... Sandoval arrives, and Cortes lurches up onto the extra ho Villafana, watching from safety, curses in disgust. As Cortes mounts the horse, he sees: His Page being carri Canoe. The Page's eyes fixed on his master.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: My page! Sandoval prevents Cortes from plunging his horse into the Enraged, Cortes tears his eyes off his Page and spurs his a swarm of Indians, cutting them down with savage intensi Sandoval are among the last Spaniards on this section of They pass Velasquez de Leon and Alvarado, bravely keeping and drive their horses into the water. Ahead of them: Marina and Two Spaniards have commandeered - accompanied by Dona Ana - are gliding to safety. Suddenly drums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And fire in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the main temple. Spaniards being led up the side. Wi recognize: Cervantes in the lead. For a moment the battle ceases and everyone on both sides in horror or triumph - as the familiar ritual is enacted: Cervantes is thrown onto the sacrificial stone. Held down. His chest is cut open. His heart is held aloft for all to see. His body is thrown callously down the side of the pyramid The Spaniards turn from the sight in shock and redouble t at escape. Now, more than ever, they are motivated by fea But scarcely have the Spanish begun anew, scarcely have C Sandoval reach the next segment of causeway, when a new s a pure piercing note... The Indians raise their arms in triumph; the Spanish turn Cuauhtemoc, blowing his conch shell: A tremulous "e" shar  113. The Indians renew their attack with a fury close to insan Cuauhtemoc's "horn" is apparently a mandate to kill, capt in the attempt. As rortes and Sandoval try to ward off the homicidal rage ack to: Alvarado and Velasquez de Leon, protecting the rear as th Spaniards enter the water. The two men fight side by side vastly different styles - Velasquez precise and aristocra Alvarado a fountain of almost homicidal fury - yet we sen them teamwork, comradeship, and, at last, mutual respect. Seeing everyone else has gone:

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Get in the water, you fool!

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON
dialogues.text: grins) Together then. (glances at Alvarado) At my signal? The glance, the camraderie, costs him. As his eyes are averted, a stone hits him on the forehead Tzilacatzin raises his arms in triumph - Velasquez de Leon falls. Alvarado leans over him -

dialogues.speaker: VELASQUEZ DE LEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Save yourself! They're beset by Indians. But Alvarado fights the Aztecs off with one arm as he hoi Velasquez de Leon onto his back. Tzilacatzin keeps firing stones which Alvarado somehow de his sword. For a few moments, like some mythological warrior, Alvara twenty men at bay with one arm. But his load is too heavy. He can't continue the swirling which protect his wounded comrade. As Alvarado's movements slow, an Indian leaps from behind for Alvarado, hits Velasquez de Leon on the back of the h Velasquez de Leon's legs stiffen... shudder...and relax. Alvarado roars with rage.  114. He drops Velasquez de Leon's body and goes on the attack. Again he drives the enemy back, but how long can he keep The water which separates him from the next section of ca filled with canoes. Impossible to swim it. He turns on his attackers, stabbing one, tossing two into water... But, totally isolated, his position appears hope He sees something. For no reason we can perceive, he laun diagonal attack, moving away from the water... They we see: A lance lying on the ground. He fights his way to it, picks it up. Too long. Indians too close to him. The lance is useless. He utters a blood-chilling roar; and the Indians fall bac instant. He points the lance toward the water and runs... His speed building, building... Indians swiping at him as he sprints past... He reaches the water and aims the lance downward, into th Like some maritime pole-vaulter, he catapults himself... out over the water... over the heads of amazed Indians in canoes... shouting with the glory of his escape... And landing near the next section of causeway. Indians ar him, but they're so amazed that they retreat. He gains la

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To the Aztecs who called Alvarado the sun, in respect for his blazing red hair, this was the most amazing feat in all our time in New Spain. You can still find the spot, in the city of Mexico, where Alvarado made his famous leap. The scene which greets Alvarado on the next dike is terri literally walking on the corpses of his comrades, many of bodies are being sacked for gold. Other Spaniards are sti struggling toward the last gap in the bridge. When he himself reaches the gap, it too is filled with fl Spanish bodies, Indian bodies... He slogs across this bridge of collapses, dodging stones arrows...  115. And reaches the last section of causeway, which connects yards ahead, a small band of Spaniards is fighting bravel Surrounding Indians pay Alvarado the courtesy of a few id thrusts, but they're primarily occupied in looting. He sprints forward and joins the rest of the group: only hundred men. They burst through the last resistance and s land. Stunned, dazed, exhausted. In a broad field, Cortes collapses under a sycamore tree. He stares blankly. Blood streams down his face. Dawn coming... Sandoval approaches wearily; the boy becoming a man. (NOT moment forward, Sandoval no longer stutters.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: The doctor must tend to your head.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) What is your reckoning?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: We have lost most of our Indian allies and two-thirds of our own men.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Tell me. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Too many to tell. Cortes glares, and Sandoval starts reciting the dead.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Juan Velasquez de Leon. Francisco de Salcedo. Francisco de Morla. Lares the Good rider. Cervantes the buffoon. Ponce the card-player - Cortes lowers his head. Weeping?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Enough?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Marina?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Safe. Cortes nods.  116.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And Lopez?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Martin Lopez, the map-maker and shipbuilder!

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Should I find out? Cortes nods. As Sandoval starts to leave -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: They have my page. (Sandoval stops) They will sacrifice my page.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: (nods; long beat) One of many. He leaves. Cortes is weeping unabashed, tears streaming d moved by this startling image...until we draw back and se In the branches over Cortes' head sits a Golden Eagle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Olmeda giving last rites to a dying soldier... The field is an outdoor hospital. Men lie groaning, other wounds, cauterizing and wrapping them. Everyone moves wit slowness, as if they were all octogenarians. Young Bernal Diaz rides into camp, comes up to Cortes. Sa approaches to get the news:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DIAZ
dialogues.text: qhey are making sacrifices to their Gods. They all know what this means.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We must thank the true God they do not attack again. They would meet little resistance.  117. Sandoval opens a small leather box. Cortes (eyes wide, fa with fever) looks on.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: From The Astrologer.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Botello? He is...? Sandoval shakes his head, and inspects Botello's papers, covered with odd markings:

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Even this little dwarf had his loyalty. "How can I survive here?" Do nothing. "How can the army survive?" Leave tomorrow night. "Then if we leave that night, I will die?" Yes. Long beat. Cristobal is approaching them -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If our man could read the future, what did Moctezuma know? What does Cuauhtemoc know now? Is the issue already decided?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: (interrupting) What are we doing? Must we sit here till the Heathens feed us to their -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No. "A wounded hare does not nap." We leave at - He stops. Stares: A familiar blond beard. Cervantes is approaching - Other Spaniards also staring. How can this be?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Cervantes! We thought you were - He stops. He sees, as we do: "Cervantes" has two right hands. And two left hands. qt is not Cervantes at all. It is an Aztec wearing Cervan skin! "Cervantes" laughs at their expressions.  118. They run at him. Stab him. He laughs until he dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pitiful sight: the severely wounded and the lame, and the remaining women, huddle in the middle. Those who cannot w or are tied to, horses. Decrepit foot soldiers surround this nucleus. A dozen hale riders and horses circumnavigate the whole. Campfires are left burning.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We departed at midnight, leaving our fires burning to fool the enemy. AS they begin their march, a SOLDIER tied to a horse has He shakes terribly, keeps shaking, but no one goes to his In fact, no one notices. He's not much worse off than any

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In our adversity, we were sustained by the knowledge that the greatest disaster had already befallen us and we had survived. But we were wrong. The greatest disaster lay ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreground blur: Spanish and Tlascalan Armies re-entering

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We returned to Tlascala. Rear of the frame, very clear: weeping Tlascalan women sc returning army for husbands, fathers, brothers, sons... A scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes lies delirious...  119. DIAZ (v.0.) Within a day, we thought our commander would die. A "surgeon" removes part of a bone from Cortes' bloody sk

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The ships! Ready the ships! Marina looks up at Sandoval:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: For hours, the same: "the ships."

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Cuba? (bitterly) | The men will be relieved. Xicotencatl the Elder is led into the tent, to Cortes' si He takes Cortes' limp hand and holds it. Frowns...cocks his head as though listening to something. And speaks. Marina responds, and the old man mutters something.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: He says it will be worse when Cortes recovers.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: What will be worse?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: The slaughter will be completed.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Of which side? She asks the old man. He spreads his arms wide: he does not know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vigil. Sandoval watches Marina apply compresses to Cortes We sense: only the care of these two people is keeping Co Softly, after a long beat:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: This..."love"...is it something you have, or something you long for?  120.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: You have it, I long for it. On Marina's hand, holding Cortes' hand: INT. TENT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Cortes, voice weak and eyes over-bright, sits facing Cris He storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernal Diaz at tall. Weeding,

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Where goes the ox that it does not draw the plow? We are soldiers! On to victory:

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: Two days ago you kissed death, now -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Martin Lopez will build our ships -

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: And sail to Cuba! They beat us! Savagely! Decisively!

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes. They showed us how to win...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: (darkly, a threat) I swear: If you pursue this course when your brain is clear... Cortes calls cheerfully, his fever raging:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Sound the trumpets! Pour the brandy! In two months I will be Don Hernando, Governor of Mexico!

dialogues.speaker: STREET. DAY.
dialogues.text: 19 is tending a tiny grove of orange trees a foot replanting, etc.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Some say we brought nothing but death and disease to this New World. It was not so. The orange pips I ppanted came up well, and grew well, and to this day all the oranges growing in New Spain descend from my trees... (beat (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not PPSEEANT tRAt these fruits, sweet though they be, are worth the life of a single Christian. Cortes, head bandaged, walks slowly past Diaz. An old man

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As Cortes recovered, he held to his plan. Walking with Cortes is Martin Lopez. We overhear them dis design of the brigantines... They reach agreement and Martin Lopez goes off, walking p Villafana and his Cohort lurking beside a building, prepa attack Cortes -

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not everyone was pleased. Cortes seems weak, helpless, unable to defend himself - But just at the moment when the traitors are about to att Marina rushes up to Cortes holding a small infant:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Hernando! He smiled! Cortes nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, he's doing it again! To you! Cortes gives the child an idle pat. They turn a corner an Ana, Moctezuma's daughter, nursing a second infant... Cortes looks at the two women, two babies...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: My wife was barren; now I have two children. If I allowed myself to feel these things, I would be happy.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: You do feel them.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I see it. He glares at her silently, then looks again toward Dona A

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: That child is descended from both me and Moctezuma...  122. Another silence as Cortes stares at Dona Ana's daughter.. Quite impulsively, Marina hands Cortes her child. To her surprise, he accepts it. The infant seizes his father's pinkie, and suddenly, unex Cortes is overwhelmed by feelings of tenderness... Marina sees it. For a moment her face is unguarded, fille and something else: longing?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: They say...that you will do anything to get what you want. A strange statement in this moment; what exactly is she a

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Of course. And what is he answering? An odd silence. He hands the child back.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am sorry. Is he apologizing for being who he is?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I am not. He looks at the child: suddenly distant from him...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If I feel this child, I will feel other things. Things which may cause me to avert my eyes in the face of danger or suffering. If I do that, even for an instant, we will all die in Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (casual) Then feel nothing. (fiercely) But love him with your secret heart. She turns from him in anger and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW PAN of the square: A kind of picnic. Spaniards loung some dressed in Indian garb, all eating Indian food with relish. They are becoming assimilated.  123.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We stayed in Tlascala six months. We see a carpentry shop: several boats under construction

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We built ships we hoped would blockade Tenochtitlan, and sent out small expeditions which conquered the Aztecs' allies. The major hidalgos are being pampered by their harems...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We also grew used to Indian ways. As we complete the PAN of the square, we find Cortes, ful recovered, speaking to his men. We don't yet hear his voi

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But pleasure is married to cowardice. We faced a final mutiny in our own midst.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (sound fading up:) ...to those of you who still doubt. You told us we could never survive our battles here in Tlascala, and you were right. You said we could not safely enter Tenochtitlan, and then leave Tenochtitlan; again you were right. You say now it is suicide to proceed; I cannot arque. By the laws of logic, you have always been right. Yet we have survived. I ask you to trust me, and follow me, one last time... (long beat) If you cannot, say it now. Cortes looks over the crowd: At Cristobal... At Villafana... Neither man speaks. Cortes nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then let us complete our miracle. The crowd cheers.  124. Cortes glances at Sandoval, and stalks toward his tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes looks at Sandoval and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Their plan is set in stone. Sandoval nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any details?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: A package will come, supposedly from Spain. As you open it, they will kill us.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: One hour.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Is Alvarado with them?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: He loves battle too much to desert.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Cristobal? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: I don't know. On Cortes' face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes, Sandoval, and Alvarado waiting. Sandoval's eyes move, see: a MESSENGER approaching with a Sandoval grunts. They all rise. As they start to walk, the Messenger intercepts them:

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Captain! A package has come from Spain.  125.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Deliver it to my tent.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: But sire -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Are you deaf? I will open it after my walk. He strolls through camp, keeping a wary eye... Some men call a greeting, others appear guilty. Villafana stands in front of his tent pretending not to l He stretches and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would die for any of them.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: That is why they hate you. They wander toward Villafana's tent.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Then what? Am I to be less than myself? He slashes a hole in Villafana's tent and jumps:

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Villafana and his Cohort conferring - They blink, stunned - Villafana grabs something from inside his shirt. Parchmen swallow it - Cortes snatches it as Alvarado and Sandoval seize the con Cortes stares at the parchment. Turns his back on the others. We, who see his face, know he has read something deeply d

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: The names? Cortes nods. Responds to the implied question:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No one of stature. Let's hope the sight of these two scares the others into submission. (turns to Villafana) Have you anything to say before you ie?  126.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: I curse the day I met you. I curse the day I heard your name. I am put on this sweet earth one time, and I curse the God who makes me die because of your mad dreams.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I am only mad if we lose. Had you followed me back to -

dialogues.speaker: VILLAFANA
dialogues.text: Had I followed, I would still have died, but I am glad to have taken this course. I had the courage to stand up to Hernan Cortes. Cortes stares at him. Villafana stares defiantly back. Cortes nods, and Alvarado gags Villafana.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (tearing up the list) My friends: we need every man. This paper did not exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great commotion. The army looks on as Sandoval and Alvara to hang Villafana and his Cohort. Cortes watches from a distance. We realize: he's not watching the hanging at all; he's wa another tent. Cristobal stands in the entrance to that tent Cortes approaches...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: A sad thing. Cristobal practically jumps. Looks toward Villafana and Cohort...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: What did they do?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Mutiny They claimed they had 50 men, but wouldn't give names.  127.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: If they had?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I would hang 50. That's why I am speaking with you. This makes Cristobal nervous. Cortes pauses, proceeds:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have often expressed an eagerness to return home -

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: But I would never -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Still, others may come to you. Others may seek your -

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: If they do, I'll tell them no.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: If they do...kill them. Cristobal nods soberly...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As_my best soldier, you are the only man I would trust to execute this sentence. Cristobal stares at Cortes...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL OLID
dialogues.text: I wish... to God... I did not love you. This is too much. Cortes spins away, to keep Cristobal fr his tortured face. He glances toward the gallows: the hanging is imminent. He sighs. Swallows.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Shall we watch? They walk toward the gallows. In the distance the bodies shudder spasmodically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgeous day. Cortes reviewing his troops: healthy, eager equipped. Our attention goes to splendor and spectacle: t the force, their Indian shields, etc. Background informat

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: While we rested in Tlascala, our forces increased. We seized two ships sent by Velasquez, and two from Jamaica. Everyone joined our army. Line after line, row after row; this army has size...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was also a ship from Spain bearing an Emissary of the Crown. Reveal from the rear: the ROYAL EMISSARY: beautiful robes spot. His head appears to be buried in a woman's chest.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He was a syphilitic old man who would not eat anything except breast milk from a woman from Castile. We now see very plainly: the old geezer is nursing. His f contented, his jaw pumping away like a newborn...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We thought he perfectly represented the bureaucracy. Cortes reaches the front of the Spanish forces.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We had 900 Spaniards, twice our original force. Farther down the hill: an endless horde of Indians.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Through conquest, we had gained 200,000 Indian allies. The Aztecs had no more. Cortes signals, and the army begins to march. A grand spe

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If this were merely a story, it would end here, and our victory would seem assured. But this is truth. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ina fewW HSFEONSnPds, our allies would desert us, our numbers would dwindle to less than 700, and we would contemplate our doom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army continuing its march with the same confidence an they crest a hill, we MOVE to the front, where we see Cor other Hidalgos looking down on the city of Tenochtitlan. The city is white. The lakes are white. Everything that lies before us: white. Shimmering in the Like snow, or flowers. A magical image. The Hidalgos exchange a look: what is it? A conch-shell trumpet blows, and the whole valley moves: White cloaks are lowered, and we realize: this is the Mex spread out over the valley, the causeways, the waters. In contrast to the Aztecs, the Spaniards look unspeakably Like an army of solid men about to do battle with spirits Cortes gestures and ever-so-slowly his forces begin to de

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army encamped. The lake is mysterious, covered with w og... Cortes stares out; Marina, Cristobal, and Sandoval at his

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: The assault is impossible. Cortes nods. All the men's faces tell us they are now sev into the battle.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We cut off their fresh water; they fight on. One of the brigantines Martin Lopes was building slips in Cortes hardly seems to notice.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our ships control their lakes disrupted their food supplies; they fight on.  130. Cortes and Marina are peering across the waters at the ma of Tenochtitlan, its towers glowing in the moonlight

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Day after day, our soldiers break into their city and kill them by the hundreds, thousands, ten thousands; they fight with undiminished rage.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (nods sadly) We will not win this war by defeating their army. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Then how...?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (softly, Staring at the city) It is so beautif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoking beams and cinders. Gutted houses: charcoal. We sw street, houses with flames still flickering. Sound up: Sc Spaniards. Spaniards with torches setting every house abl hell. Fire as fury, revenge, all the Spanish frustration with sadistic glee..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLYING CAMERA, chaotic images; swirling flashes of blood, smoke. Out of control in some horrible/satisfying way. RA through the flames out onto: THE LAKE. DAY. Houses on stilts, blazing all across the water. Alvarado burning house, carrying booty. His brig sails to the next building. Passing the floating once blooming and beautiful, now dry as dust. Roof of a nearby house: two Aztec women and a very old ma fear and confusion on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To the Aztecs, war was a ritual activity, a religious rite whose object was to obtain captives for sacrifice. They did not understand why we burned their houses. To them it was stupid and mean; it showed we were heathens, devils of destruction whose purposes were beyond understanding.  131. Alvarado and his men jump off the brig and climb the step adjacent dwelling. Guns drawn, they enter: INT. AZTEC HOUSE. DAY. Two gaunt women and three children curl in a corner, terr bodies are emaciated. While his men search for valuables, Alvarado tries to sho occupants out the door

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: Move, you idiots! Go! Now! Get out! He stares at them in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Light it up, they'll go. His men torch the far corner.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Alvarado and his men run down the steps, watching the fir A ramshackle canoe waits at the bottom of the steps. The corner of the house which was torched is now blazing. Those inside will have to leave soon. They do not. Within moments, the entire house is ablaze. There was never any movement to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Marina are eating their dinner. Just like a marrie Only Cortes has no appetite. Finally he puts down his fork Looks at her. She stares back. Completely accepting, waiting...

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: It was my greatest hope to preserve this city for the world to marvel. b (beat) (MORE)  132. Who am I90RAES(FONRtDAo I have to make such decisions?

dialogues.text: you donвЂ™ t make them, no one wal If you don't make them, we will all die.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Perhaps that would be better. He stares at her a long time...

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In all of this, you are the one thing which has no bitterness. The tenderest look between them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes, eyes gleaming, exhorts his men across a break in causeway. We sense for the first time: incipient triumph.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next day our army, fighting on three separate causeways, pressed to the heart of the city. Crossing the channel, the Spaniards rage on, Cortes in th

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Once across the channels, we did not fill them in. We smelled victory, and gave no thought to retreat. EXT. TENOCHTITLAN. STREETS. DAY. On Cortes' face, as he rides. In his excitement, we sense his drive: something intensely charismatic and very ugly. Around Cortes, we feel his army: other horsemen at his si running behind... Aztecs screaming, retreating... We stay on his face. The triumph of the will. The masculi sexual thrill of conquering. And then he turns a corner and his features change. Suddenly blank. Staring at: Impaled on stakes: heads of previously captured Spaniards The giant Tzilacatzin, laughing -  133. Mocking whistles from all directions - Cortes and the other soldiers, disoriented - "E" sharp. On a rooftop: Cuauhtemoc blows his bugle - Aztecs manifest, everywhere. Instantaneous assault - Spaniards overwhelmed, pulled from their horses - Total chaos -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indians surging forward like a huge wave, breaking ov Spaniards - For an instant all we can see are the cloaks of the Aztec over? So quickly? Cortes surfaces. Then two more Spaniards. Twenty yards aw spot: Alvarado - But fighting is almost impossible. The enemy is too thick Spaniard after another is dragged away - Cortes bleeding, fighting, three Indians on his back shou "Malinche! Malinche!" - Alvarado makes his way to Cortes' side. dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Nonsense. , ALVARADO ; . It is all a man could want, in this life, to have fought here with you.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: No what?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Your words are sweet but ill-timed. This is not the end.

dialogues.speaker: ALVARADO
dialogues.text: (grins with admiration) Then let's get out of here! Cortes leaps onto the back of an Indian, quickly looks ar ducks as another Indian flies over his head, trying to gr Comes down again and points:  134.

dialogues.text: The horses. Now that the two men have a purpose, they fight with redo energies. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the victory the Aztec Gods had promised. This was the disaster we had feared for two interminable years. As the massacre continues, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post battle. Wounded men all over. Sandoval peers into the distance... An Indian Translator at his side says:

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: They say they have won victories on all three causeways. Out in a canoe, Indians hold up three Spanish heads. Impo this distance, to discern their features.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are the heads of Cortes Alvarado, Cristobal. Sandoval nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: So it would seem. (calls) Page! Page! Bring my horse! His page comes running with the large chestnut -

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MEXICAN TERRITORY. DUSK.
dialogues.text: Sandoval riding low and fast, without armor... Mexicans trying to hit him with arrows, stones; he's too  135. From his intense expression, we realize: his mission is p

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CORTES' CAMP. DUSK.
dialogues.text: Sandoval rides in. Dismounts and enters:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES' TENT
dialogues.text: Cortes weak and disheartened. Leg bandaged, both arms, hi For the first time, we see age on his face... It's as if escape has sapped him of his strength and spirit.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: They said you were dead. Cortes nods as if it were true.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: My sins are the cause of this. I pressed too hard, too fast, we did not fill the channel -

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Still. We have survived this day too.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Why? Sandoval looks at him in consternation and shock

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why have we survived?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: His spirits are low.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I'm being honest! (bitter) I told them to fill the channel, but they "forgot!" For the first time, he is blaming someone else.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Then...was it your fault or theirs?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (pauses) Mine. All mine. And now...have you heard about our Indian allies? (off Sandoval's look) They desert us in the morning.  136.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: shrugs) Ask them. A terrible banging of drums. The great huehetl atop the p Cortes and Sandoval exchange a glance. Louder drums. Regular beating. In apprehension, they leave the tent. EXT. TENT. NIGHT. They come out, look into the distance. A few miles away, so close you can almost touch it with y A parade marching up the side of the main cue: Brightly lit by torches. In the center: 30 naked SPANIARD

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Am I next? Or you? Not said with fear or fatalism; almost with relief.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: You cannot say such things! If you despair, we will all -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We have what, 700 wounded men? Moctezuma was right: there isa destiny, and we will meet ours whether I despair or not. He stares at the temple. The train has reached the top; something strange is happe Feathers are put on the heads of the Spanish captives. They are naked, forced to dance grotesquely, with fans... some bizarre homosexual game...only this one ends in deat

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: I can't watch.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (with disdain) Then avert your eyes. The first Spaniard is tied to the sacrificial stone. His contorted in screams; we hear nothing.  137. In camp: Other soldiers watch, trying to swallow their fe On the pyramid: the first Spaniard's heart is held aloft. Canoes glide past the camp and Aztecs shout tauntingly... Marina reacts, glances anxiously at Cortes, then at the g Finally, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: This is what scares our Indian allies. (hesitates; she is worried) The say. Their Gods proclaim we will all die within eight days. Cortes stares at her. Blinks. Looks at the canoes. Back at Marina. At Sandoval. A touch of fire returning to his eyes. Mixed with irony: until he gives up that he wins. When he speaks, it is to

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: The war is over.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Never say it! If I have learned one thing from you -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (quietly) For eight days we must keep to our camps. Simply maintain the blockade. Sandoval is pleased to glimpse the return, however muted, the leader.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We'll still be here. Their prophecy, their law, will be proved false. Their bodies will be weak from hunger, thirst. They will peer into the abyss and contemplate their own defeat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: No attacks?  138.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No. Wars are won in the mind, not in the field.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: And for we few who have strength?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Tf you have energy to burn...use

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No people. Birds moving around, chirping. We notice the thick lattice of sticks which keep them in. Slowly, with a kind of horror, we realize what we're abou Glow of a flame nearby, off-screen. Gradually it MOVES INTO FRAME. Torch. Birds begin to flutter nervously, twittering in discordan The torch moves down, out of frame again. Lights the latt A YOUNG SOLDIER doing it. Stands back to watch. No guilt. Birds start to scream - Flames catching fast, spreading... Birds whirling frantically, beaks distorted - Some fly directly into the flame and incinerate. Others crash into each other and plunge into the fire - The humming/flapping sound of many wings... As the blaze spreads, a piece of the latticework crashes Making a hole in the ceiling through which a few birds fl At the top, the GOLDEN EAGLE caws loudly. Flames spiral upward, toward it - The Golden Eagle squeezes through a hole in the latticewo hole always there? Could the bird have left at any time? It soars into the sky, squawking its protest. Below it, the other birds have become flying incinerators their fellows ablaze.  139. We watch helplessly. The destruction of civilization. The incineration of something unspeakably beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes, much recovered, watches as his soldiers slaughter all sexes in the big. The enemy still has the will, but n strength, to fight back. Far in the distance, the whole c

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (in genuine anguish) Why do they fight on? We begged them to surrender, were refused, and we killed ten thousand in a day. We begged again, refused again, and our allies killed forty thousand. How many warriors can they have left?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: A few hundred.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: So why don't they surrender? Cristobal shrugs. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I know why. beat ) I heard them say. (beat ) They think...that you are cowards. Silence. Bewilderment as Cortes tries, without success, t this thought. Marina continues:

dialogues.speaker: MARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To them, war is hand-to-hand combat, designed to reveal the will of the Gods. They think it is cowardly to kill from a distance, with guns and crossbows, cowardly to retreat if you are losing a battle, cowardly and immoral to win a war by starving the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And this is why -

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Would you concede to cowards, to heathens who gain victory by vicious and unfair means?  140. Cortes looks again at the slaughter of Aztecs only a hund away. He sees it now, if only for an instant, in a differ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes leads his army into the deserted main square. Stops his horse, looks around. Sensing something...someth The square feels spooky. Magical.. Haunted... Cortes feels it...and ignores it. Spurs his horse on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes peering through his telescope, into the distance: Only one small sector of the city remains standing. Father Olmeda is at Cortes' side. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No one will believe I love the Aztec. There is no courage, anywhere in the world, that will compare.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: That is easy to say, since you have won.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: What do you say, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: What you accomplished here defies human understanding. Countless times we were doomed, yet here we stand. As strong as you are, as full of guile and courage, you would never have achieved this had it not been the will of God. He willed it, so it is. You were merely his instrument. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: , CORTES
dialogues.text: Praise be His Name.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER OLMEDA
dialogues.text: God's name? ...or yours?  141. Cortes flashes him an angry look. Then lifts his spyglass and looks out over the water, whe brigantine is chasing three piroques.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After a 93 day siege, the war ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandoval in the brigantine, chasing the swift and brightl pirogues. As the brigantine draws close, Sandoval fires a shot in t Two beats. Then Cuauhtemoc, in the center canoe, stands. Long stunned silence. Just this one man standing, and the in all who witness of what it means... And the drums which have been beating for 93 days, for 20 film, suddenly stop. It is suddenly, frighteningly, quiet

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: I_am Cuauhtemoc. Lead me to Malinche Let no harm come to my wife and friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes sits on Moctezuma's mat as Cuauhtemoc is led in. The Royal Emissary is at Cortes' side. His Wet Nurse hove feet behind. Cortes rises and touches the ground, then his chest, then "My heart and my mind welcome you." Cuauhtemoc, looking very much like Moctezuma, bows in rep

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: I_have done all I could to defend my city. As the victor, you have sacrificed my people to yur God. (kneels, indicates Cortes' sword, and lowers his head) I_beg you: rid me of my life.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Please. You are still the Emperor and will be treated with honor. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Spaniaf@RTESPEONS 'Palor even in an enemy. And this is your wife? Behind Cuauhtemoc we see CUAUHTEMOC'S WIFE, a girl of 16, Cuauhtemoc nods. Cortes rises and kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The youngest daughter of the great Moctezuma. I loved your father and know your sister well. But you are even more beautiful... Marina translates. Cuauhtemoc's wife blushes.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will take good care of you, as I promised your father. Little ambiguity as to what this means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes turns back to Cuauhtemoc:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great Speaker, there is one thing I must ask: Where is the gold? The riches? We have searched your city... As Marina translates, Cuauhtemoc shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: I_do not know. Some say it was thrown into the lake. His eyes are clear. Telling the truth. Cortes nods, seems to accept this, but a grunt comes from The Royal Emissary gesturing. Cortes' jaw tightens and he Apparently they've had some previous discussion. Cortes m Sandoval to go to the Emissary:

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Tell the Soldiers to burn Cuauhtemoc's feet. Burn them till he remembers. Sandoval, his face flickering with anger, returns to Cort

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Is this your order too? Cortes glances with barely concealed contempt at the Emis  143.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then prevent it.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: This is no longer war. We must bow our heads to the king or he will cut them off.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: But what of courage?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Useless.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Honor?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: We can conquer the world, but we cannot save this man from torture. Sandoval stares at Cortes.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: I will not order it. Cortes' jaw tightens. He turns, whispers to a nearby SOLD Soldier goes off to prepare the torture. Sandoval is still staring, contemptuously, at Cortes.

dialogues.speaker: CUAUHTEMOC
dialogues.text: Malinche, if I am still Chief of the Aztecs, I must ask one thing: that_my people be allowed to leave this city in safety, for here only starvation and pestilence remain.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (nods; tells his men:) Peaceful evacuation may begin immediately. (to Cuauhtemoc) Go. Go now and rest. Cuauhtemoc nods and bows. The Soldier who is to arrange the foot-burning leads Cuau Cuauhtemoc's wife starts to follow -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sadly, the rules of war dictate that men, who are prisoners, must be kept apart from their families. Cuauhtemoc's wife is led in a different direction. Marina watching this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortes looks at her, at Sandoval. To Sandoval:

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: (to Marina, re: Cuauhtemoc's wife) Is she my first mistress? (to Sandoval) Is this the first time we burn someone? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Sire? Do you need me now? For translation? He stares at her. Was there some disrespect in her attitu imagining it?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: No. But stay. You of all people deserve some reward for this amazing conquest. (beat ) Would you like to be an honest woman?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I have always been so, sire. Certainly with you.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes, but you deserve to be married.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I know I am already. Her look says: To you. He looks at her for a long moment. We feel his impulse to her, to follow through on his love, his passion. And her eyes say she is ready... Though of course, as an will accept anything. Finally he looks away from her -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Sandoval. Don't you think Marina deserves a proper Christian ceremony?  145.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: (pleased, touched) Yes, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: But who should be the groom? The cold question moves like ice through Sandoval's heart

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: The one who loves her.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Must that "one" marry her?

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: It would be an act worthy of Cortes. To say across this land that Spaniard and Indian are now joined. Again, for an instant, Cortes himself is caught by this i once again it turns.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: How sweet. How simple. Cortes glances at the Royal Emissary. Sandoval blinks, realizing...

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: What? You...? You mean if you wed a "savage," it might impede your chances for nobility?

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: It would. But surely I'm not the only candidate. There must be others who desire this lovely squaw. (looks around the room, then back at Sandoval) Perhaps even you would...? (before Sandoval can answer) No. Of course not, I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know Sandoval would marry her, does love her, but Cort really want to risk losing her affections by proposing su He quickly: Moves away from Sandoval, goes down the line of Spanish soldiers...and stops in front of DON JARAMILLO, a man rem for his total absence of remarkable qualities.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Captain, you are Don... (barely remembering name) Jaramillo, are you not?  146.

dialogues.speaker: JARAMILLO
dialogues.text: Yes, sire.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Would you take this lovely woman for your bride? Jaramillo's paralyzed. Is this a trick? Is Cortes seeking for a beheading?

dialogues.speaker: JARAMILLO
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't presume to -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: I am asking you to marry her! Do you accept?!

dialogues.speaker: JARAMILLO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Of course, sir. I'd be honored to sleep w - to marry - your (mistress) .I mean to say -

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And you, Marina, would you take this man for a husband? She stares at Cortes. Wounded. Sorry for him. And yet kno understanding... everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: It would be a great great honor... to be a Spanish noblewoman.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Father Olmeda. Please take this couple to some distant room and perform the holy sacrament. Olmeda bows, offended but obedient, and starts away. Jaramillo follows. Marina does not move. They look at each other. An exquisitely painful moment. C doing what - by the ethics of his time - was the very bes noblest thing he could do. But it is still offensive to h heart, and to Marina's, and to ours.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do not forget...in your marital bliss ...that you are still on call, day and night, to perform translation.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: I am, as always, at your service.  147. She_bows deeply. . sand backs away, eyes on him... Finall follow her husband. Cortes turns his back on her...and on the entire company. window. Tears in his eyes... Sandoval follows.

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: Sir. Cortes will not look at him. But somehow, when he finally does, his eyes are dry.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Yes, my son. SANDOVAL. W-w-what is happening? Sandoval's nervousness has brought back his stutter.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: To me? Haven't you heard? I'm a God, I can do anything. Sandoval stares at him in consternation, rage, despair...

dialogues.speaker: SANDOVAL
dialogues.text: I always said I would f-follow you even to my death...and I've fought with you many times at its brink... But_I can no longer...f-f fights the stutter) follow you at all. Cortes nods. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: And I no longer need you. That is the hard truth. (long beat) Now I stand alone. Sandoval withdraws. Cortes stares out the window. As he does, we realize that a horn is blowing outside, an that Cortes' order, requested by Cuauhtemoc, is already b out. The Aztecs are leaving the city. Old men, women, children. Skeletal: hollow eyes, shrivele Look like survivors of Hiroshima.  148. Cortes watches them go.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was two years before Cortes was proclaimed Governor of New Spain. The job quickly bored him. Cortes turns from the window and lowers his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He set off again and again to conquer new lands, to repeat his glory, but he never did anything comparable. (beat) Neither did anyone else. Cortes turns back to face the room. Marina is gone. Sandoval is gone. Everyone else is waiting on him... He sees that they would wait forever. Literally.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: People ask: was he a great man? Undoubtedly. A good man? No. A good man never would have achieved these things. With an air of command that is unassailable, Cortes shout

dialogues.speaker: CORTES
dialogues.text: Raise the purple pendant of Castile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The purple Castilian flag flaps in the breeze above the c it: The Aztec exodus. Broken bodies, vessels for broken spirits. Tzilacatzin: still alive but somehow no longer a Giant. H deep and black, shoulders stooped; the skin hangs off his he were an old man. But the faces of the children are what is impossible to w young yet void, without soul.  149. Following our impulse to avert our eyes, we look away, up sky: Far overhead, a Golden Eagle is flying. Flying away. Not in the same direction the people are going. No. Somewhere else. Into hiding... or seclusion... or extinction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children (white, Indian, mestizo, and mulatto) are playin a_grove of orange trees laden with fruit. Nearby, BERNAL old man sits at a wooden table writing with a quill.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Three years later, Cortes ordered Cuauhtemoc hung, on dubious charges of treason. He pauses, looks out at the orange trees, resumes.

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Aztec civilization was destroyed. Their spirit broken, their Gods discredited, the people died out. If you travel here to Mexico, only a few statues and pieces of jewelry remain. The orange trees are shimmering in the wind...

dialogues.speaker: DIAZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Today, the third of April, 1576, I look back and my heart is filled wit pride at what we accomplished. eat But my eyes are filled with tears. FADE OUT...  150.
